content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												Absolutely loved this game. Got fairly obsessed with it over the last week (sorry to my friends who were flooded with screenshots...) and when it came time to beat it I was pretty sad. It has a lot of great gameplay, great storyline and fun characters. It was definitely not a dull game and it's pretty in depth considering all the questing you have to do. I played with the DLCs Air Temple and Treasure Island which I suggest getting. The Pirate Clothes DLC does offer decent EQ, but it's nothing to write home about once you get into the meat of the game. Still somewhat handy after becoming a Pirate.My suggestions for others looking to play this game is to use a guide. You can easily get quests mixed up which will lock you out of completing or even participating in others. Save often in case this happens so you can go back and not have to spend hours toiling to get to the same spot you left off of.This also applies to if you are an achievement hound like I can be and want to 100% this game. It is possible, but there are decisions that can affect whether you get a certain achievement or not. Again - save at critical points. The game only allows you 10 save files (afaik), but if you are smart about it, that should be enough. Another heads up with achievements, certain ones the counter will reset to 0 once you completely exit the game. But achievements will count multiple save files, so at least there's that. (kill, reload, repeat!)Overall, if you love RPGs, Pirates, Questing and Monster killing - this is the game for you.And just FYI, it does have some rough edges which didn't bother me in the least but I am sure other players might find to be hinderances. The game play can be a bit clunky and there are some glitches, but, as I mentioned before, using a guide at least for reference will save you a lot of hair from being ripped out.Update: I just finished Risen and it was fantastic. This game is still my favorite and I really, really wish it had been longer because I love Pirate Captain Nameless Hero so dang much.I did notice a couple of inconsistencies in story line between the two games but it was so minor they aren't even worth mentioning. Plus it gives y'all something to look out for. ;)

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												Note: Copy-Paste from my review of Risen 1. You shouldn't play Risen 2 without having played Risen 1. Personal rating: 8/10Replayability: MediumBudget: Worth it. Lenght: A few days to a week. Risen 2 specific notes: Risen 2, apart from what I have to say about the series in general below, has a slightly clumsy combat system, and feels like a partial attempt at making a Sid-Meyer's Pirates! inspired RPG, but remains a very good game. I'm not sure what to think of Risen. The company behind Risen made Gothic, a series that I loved. Gothic has a tragic story, funding was cut from the expansion pack to the third installment, resulting in a buggy game that felt unfinished, and had the wrong voice-actors. The dreaded fourth installment that the orginal company wasn't even part of, killed the series, and I hear this is why they started Risen on the side. While I was initially excited about Risen, I feel like Risen is some sort of attempt from the company's side to "win back" their original ideas for gothic. It feels like they're trying to make the same game, but different. Still, Risen has a decent story, but Risen is a series, and the third installment just game out. I'll try not to judge Risen 1 on the sequels, but it's hard, because frankly Risen 2 feels like they retconned a lot of Risen 1 in an attempt to reboot their franchise as a sort of "pirate age" age game, even though it clearly felt like a high-fantasy gothic medieval game in the first installment. Separately though, the games are quite good, it's just a bit of a snag to get over how poorly they connect, despite several characters making appearances in both games. In many ways, Risen perfectly embodies the spirit of Gothic and does provide some not-seen-before elements. Where in Gothic, you felt like you were the nameless master-mind behind a gang of anti-heroes who follow you out of some misguided sense of loyalty (honor among thieves, I guess) rather than true friendship, always facing challenges in a hostile world as you go about, in Risen you feel like people actually have a more "human" relationship towards you. Sure, you're still a nameless guy but apart from a select few individuals, you're truly alone this time, but your friendships in the game are based on actual frienship, meaning the character actually has some relationships with people. Risen in no way beats or threatens the legacy of the 3 real gothic games, but if you liked gothic, you NEED to play Risen too. Fun fact: Many fans believe that unofficially, Risen is set several years in the future of the original gothic trilogy. Read more on this theory on the internet.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												Risen 2 is a weird, confused mess of a game. Its half post-apocalyptic/lovecraftian horror and half swashbuckling lighthearted pirate adventure and neither of the two meet to make a solid whole. Throughout the 30 or so hours of the game, both sides seem like totally different things, with the pirate adventure taking up the lions share of the spotlight.Risen 2 also continues on with Risen's goal of simplifying mechanics that date all the way back to the Gothic games. Fast travel and a more robust XP system cause Risen 2 to move more towards the Action RPG archetype at times. This isn't to say that all the complexity has been bred out of Risen 2, the Learning Points system still exists, mostly, but is instead gated by Glory (XP) and knowledge level of the five character attributes. This more or less works, but something is definitely lost in translation and Risen 2's gameplay begins to feel more like generic RPG systems instead of the interesting systems in Gothic and Risen.The combat loop in Risen 2 is also vastly simplified and the game is overall orders of magnitude more easier then it's predecessors, with the more thoughtful combat systems in both Risen and the Gothic games replaced with hack'n'slash mechanics. I got through the entire game just mashing on the attack button and peridocally shooting people while mashing on my health position hotkey during the few times i was in peril. Overall, it's nowhere near as satisfying as the previous games, which made you *work* to survive encounters with even basic enemies. Also, you can still get stunlocked to death in Risen 2, so at least there is some connective tissue to the previous games!Storywise, the game takes a *lot* of inspiration from the Pirates of the Caribbean ride/movies, especially in it's use of voodoo and pirate curses as a main story theme. The nameless character from Risen has become a Inquisition officer in the years between the games and resides in the Crystal Fortress in Caldera, the last human city of the 'Old World' after all the previous ones have been destoryed by not only Titans themselves, but also a cataclysmic conflict between the Titan Lords, one of which the main character helped resurrect and free in the previous game. Humanity stands on the brink of annihilation due to being unable to fight back against the Titans *and* Titan Lords, especially Mara, a Titan, and her kraken, who holds the Southern Seas and has sent countless ships to the bottom of the sea, which means that supplies and fresh troops are dangerously low in Caldera. After a ship heading for the Crystal Fortress is destroyed by Mara's kraken, Patty, a somewhat important character from Risen, washes up on the shores and teams up with the nameless character after he is told to go undercover as a pirate to investigate rumors of weapons that are capable of killing Mara that are held by Steelbeard, Patty's estranged father. The story is serviceable and does the job of providing a reason to go on a grand adventure, but there was never a point where I cared at all about the events of the game, especially considering the immense tone whiplash that I got after coming off the first game. It honestly feels like Piranha Bytes had one team making an actual sequel to Risen and another making a pirate RPG and they just smushed the two together. A lot of characters that previously existed in Risen act nothing like their former incarnations, with the main character being the most egregious example.Graphically, the game is capable of some really nice jungle environments and some great lighting, but most of the time it looks very average, especially in terms of very average looking character models and animations. There is nothing here that will push your hardware to the max or make your jaw drop, and I was comfortably able to run it on max settings without breaking a sweat. The art style is nothing to write home about as well, there was nothing notable at all except for the aforementioned jungle environments. The most offensive thing I can think of in terms of the graphical features is that lighting in caves and ruins is exceptionally poor. It attempts to convey a dark environment, but instead just causes me to be unable to see, even with torches. I had to increase the brightness just to see what I was doing in these areas.One important thing to note too is that I ran into many bugs playing this game. During all 35 hours of play, I was never able to either make a hard save through the menu or use the console without the game instantly crashing to desktop. I still have no idea what causes this and googling and asking around brings no fixes. There were also bugs with some achievements never triggering, non-critical items never spawning and things like that. I used the Risen 2 Unofficial Patch, which purports to fix many non-critical issues with quests and the like, but I still ran into these problems, so be aware.Also, Risen 2 has some gross bits in it, especially with the way native peoples are portrayed in the game, where they basically just took every existing colonialist 'tribal' stereotype in media and smooshed them all into one, kinda offensive mess.  There is also some blatant homophobia with one character that seems incredibly unnecessary. Overall, I did actually have fun with this game, but it is also a very average game when examined critically. If you are hankering for a game with pirate adventures in it and you have exhausted everything to do in Assassin's Creed 4: Black Flag, give this a whirl. It has some charm to it, but it's not gonna be a game that you fondly remember after you finish it. Unofficial Patch: http://forum.worldofplayers.de/forum/threads/1154440-release-Risen-2-Unofficial-Patch

												This game totally deviates from the system of the company (Pirahna Byte's) 's previous game series (Gothic), despite the fact that the previous game in the same series played out in almost exactly the same way.Risen 1 was a challenging but very functional and very enjoyable open-world action rpg. The combat could be difficult and frustrating, but if you took the time to figure things out there was a good way to handle every situation.In Risen 2 they completely trash the functional combat Risen 1 had in exchange for a combat system where all you do is wail on the enemy until they fall over, or else run away until the cooldown on your gun is over and then just shoot, rinse & repeat. The timing and different methods of attack don't factor in significantly because regular methods of dealing damage don't have a notable effect.Risen 1 is a very enjoyable shout-out to a classic rpg series (Gothic), Risen 2 is a piece of crap.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												With Risen 3 just over a month away, I thought I'd add my input for anyone who might pick this up, expecting to get an impression of the series. Warning: this is a long review, so for a brief summary, just skip to the end paragraph.The original Risen was, fundamentally, a sound, well-executed, and generally enjoyable fantasy RPG experience, if a bit unimagined and simple. It had everything that made the studio (Piranha Bytes) known in the fantasy RPG market, including memorable NPC's with dynamic behaviors and daily routines to give the game world an organic, living setting. The combat system was decent, but a bit glitchy, and magic offered an interesting, varied complement to combat and exploration. While mostly taking place in a single outdoor landmass, the game also transitioned (seamlessly, I might add) to deep, ruined dungeons which stretched from brief to expansive, and all very nicely designed.Risen 2: Dark Waters lost a lot of that. Abandoning the medieval fantasy theme for a pirate setting, and giving up the single landmass for individual islands separated by loading screens, it's not wrong of you to expect a game with a lot of open-sea activities and exploration and loot-filled adventure. That's not what you get. You find yourself on foot the entire time, running around tiny islands that you soon realize are even smaller than they appear due to deliberate landscape design, turning what could be immersive wilderness exploration into a boring run along pathways between mountains and rocky cliff faces. Dungeons are small, tubular caves or cookie-cutter ruined hallways that rarely yield memorable loot.Whereas previous games from Piranha Bytes gave us NPC's that we could laugh at and remember, there's very little to make us like the batch of characters in this title. Patty, the supposed "love interest" of the player character, is the most expressive NPC by far, but is still a pretty generic representation of a typical pirate fantasy trope of a female character trying to prove her strength and independence amongst the tough, grizzled men in the piratey world. The follower Bones offered a bit of humor, but apart from that, I couldn't care less about the characters. Only four NPC's (including Patty) make the crossover between Risen and Risen 2, and two of those characters only appear in the DLC's, and none of them truly reflect their former selves, so anyone whom you might have loved and hoped to see from Risen won't be here.The combat system is what drives many people to complain about this game. In the beginning, I can certainly agree with them - until you get some of the upper-tier skills, which allow you to parry and counter enemy attacks, you're left only with the ability to spam the attack button and hope that everything else dies before you do. The bigger problem is getting those skills. The opening area of the game, Tacarigua, encourages you to invest in a wide variety of skills, but there is no chance of you getting them all so soon - learning skills requires not only levelling up your stats, but paying teachers a huge sum to instruct you, and gold is not easily acquired this early in the game. By the time you get the upper tier combat skills, you'll be used to spamming attacks and depending on your followers, so you may never actually discover how useful parrying and riposting really is.On the topic of skills, you can safely ignore about half of the skills the game offers. Many of them have such selective usefulness in so few occasions that they aren't worth investing in at all. Partway through the game, you're forced to make a decision that decides what skills will be open to you later - either being able to use muskets, or voodoo magic. Voodoo may sound like the more attractive option, but in my experience, it's almost completely worthless. Many enemies later in the game are immune to the spells, and potions are such short-term buffs that they're a waste of time to fuss with. Still, it hardly matters which side you choose, because even if you forego muskets for voodoo, you can still use shotguns (or 'shotgun,' since I think only one exists in the game), which function exactly the same.The only one thing I can actually give credit to this game for is the "legendary items" feature. Starting with the expansion for Gothic II, Piranha Bytes has included a series of hidden treasures in each of their games to seek out and dig up. Risen included pieces of broken weapons that could be reforged into powerful swords. This was included in Risen 2 as well, but the game also featured legendary items that could be read about in books found throughout the settlements of the world, and offered clues leading to special items giving passive perks to your character. This feature was the only thing that made the islands truly worth exploring, as the majority of loot you found in dungeons and the landscape was little more than fodder to dump onto a vendor for a quick buck.All in all, Risen 2: Dark Waters fails in its promise to give us the first true pirate RPG. It fails to give us an endearing RPG experience of any kind, in fact. Calling it "streamlined" is too forgiving, as the whole game is woefully shallow; with an assortment of useless skills to waste money on, small, unimagined islands that offer little incentive to explore, and characters that, at best, are simply mind-numbing caricatures of the common stereotypes of Hollywood pirates. This title is an offense to the legacy of Piranha Bytes, and it fills me with dread to know that the developers of four quintessential RPG's could sink this low. Here's hoping Risen 2 was a bitter lesson for the studio, and while I expect RIsen 3: Titan Lords to have some of the same flaws (with their shortest development time so far, I can't expect it to be a complete turn-around), I can only hope we see some signs of life in the future to indicate that they can provide us with another beloved RPG for the ages.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2016
												        Risen 2 is a third-person RPG that made me spend a lot of time on it. You are a former Inquisition soldier that travels from nearly destroyed Caldera across the seas to various islands. The setting is quite immersive: Carribean-like islands, treasure hunt, grave plundering, pirate fights, the Creed....all of that you can experience here. The more you talk to the people in the game, the more details of story and quests you discover. From the drinking adventurer at the beginning to the captain of your own ship  in the end you will fight Mara using four artifacts that you have to get from each captain. 	At first sight, the plot is distinct, linear but during the playthrough lots of interesting quests and events emerge. The goal of the game is to get all four artifacts to fight against the “she-devil” Mara. Each artifact has special means to be acquired. You will have to fight against titans, escape from the island after being marooned by one of the captains, build a raft with the help of gnomes and reveal the mascarade of another captain who killed the Inquisition soldiers and used their robes to gain trust from the Marakayas.  The game is filled with lots of side-quests.  A part of these quests suggest different wayouts due to your talents or your personal attitude. Points of glory that you get for fighting and completing tasks help you improve your skills. You can be a trickster, a fighter, a brute or a voodoo master. Better choose from the beginning what type of skills you will develop the most.  Hence, you can either intimidate or flatter people or simply do a point-blank shoot (if a script suggests) and many more.  Also it is worth mentioning that you can get such useful abilities as kicking over opponents, training monkeys and parrots to steal things and distract foes. There are some unique collectibles that require from you having certain of  the above mentioned abilities to get them.  Other abilities include the use of a voodoo doll to take direct control of other characters or rituals to weaken opponents. But the most hilarious tricks are breathing fire in the opponent's face, scattering sand in the eyes and dropping coconuts. This one was one of the highlights for me. Thorough exploration also awards you with unique items and treasure maps. The more gold you get, the more skills you can master from trainers all over the playground. Also you can use potions, parts of clothes and weapons that boost your skills. There certainly is a value in replay as the game suggests to play either for the Inquisition or for the local tribes. Personally I preferred learning cunning skills primarily and then slashing and piercing weapons because I rarely use magical skills in RPGs. This helped me open lots of chests, train monkeys and parrots, also complete quests using eloquent speech which was fun for me. The main hero could use sarcasm, jokes or steal gold. Voodoo is also a fun way. It helps you control people after getting some of their personal things and making a voodoo doll. And it unlocks another branch of quests.	There were enough animals and monsters in the game world. After killing them you can use their parts for trading or for magic. But not at once. You must get special tools at first: bone saw, ritual knife and others. The faster you find them, the better. This also encouraged me to explore.	Music and sound effects are decent, I wish there would be more ambient or combat soundtracks though. Sometimes it weakens the desire to play the game. From the other side, the main hero has his own voiceover, unlike in some other RPGs. This is crucial for me, adds an immersion. The best soundtrack is at the moment when the ghost of Captain Steelbeard appears at the Island of the Dead. Moreover, every companion that goes with you during the quests may also add some witty sentences in the cutscenes. Generally, the voiceover of the main characters is good. I appreciated that. Only the animations of body language repeat too much. 	Graphics are demanding. It was hard for me to optimize the game to get normal fps. I sacrificed with draw distance and detail quality, downloaded a small fix that boosts fps from Steam community and changed some values in “ini” files. Then nothing was critical, the game can be completed at 20-25 fps, at dark and foggy places it drops to 15-18 fps on my old PC. I only regret that I could not pass shooting challenge in Antigua because it was impossible to aim and hit targets. Luckily, there was another quest to skip it and played on.	Another problem that I spotted is linked with achievements. Many of them are unlockable. For example, I definitely killed more than 20 giant crabs and unlocked more than 100 chests by the end of the game, but these achievements just do not pop up. Neither in game, nor in Steam and there is almost a dozen of them. Playing hours do not count properly too. My last save file has around 40 hours, Steam shows 19 or so.		Nevertheless, I kept hooked on this game because I tried upgrading the skills and wanted to see what if I tried to pass a certain quest having this or that talent. So, overall if counting the replays, the game will take good 60 hours approximately. If you like pirate themed RPGs, main heroes with a sense of humour and breaking the rules, this game is a good pick. Aye-aye, gamers!

												I had a good time playing this nice adventure game. Good graphics, good voiceovers and music, nice story and  enough side quests to keep me busy for about 150 hours.  And a good sense of humor as well! Of course it is not perfect, Everyone uses the same handull of gestures, the fighting is very simple. Actually I liked that. I did not play this game as a fight game, but as to follow a fun and nice story.  For me the game succeeded very well at that. Of course there is a lot of fighting, but no one is really hard to beat. I did not even invest in learning fighting skills. About investing...it is very hard to make gold, so be very carefull on what choises you make when spending money. A bit too hard even! I did get used to it, just not expecting to be able to really buy anything or learn a lot of skills. Just learned to get by with what i got. Stealing and lockpicking is a great way to get cash. I would advice to  invest in thievery, rather then fighting because of the reason mentionned earlier. Ow and you can become a voodoo pirate. I did not look into that a lot myself, but you can control other people's minds, which i think is cool.All and all...a great game to pick up on sale, because it is a bit old (2012) I would not pay full price on it. DEFINITELY RECOMMENDED!

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Risen 2: Dark Waters is a very glitchy and at times very tedious pirate RPG game. If you are honestly wanting to play an RPG, I would suggest you try the Witcher or Skyrim, as your time would be better spent with those games. In regards to Risen 2, I will say this: the combat is broken and frustrating for the most part, there are all manner of glitches which break any sort of immersion you have in the game, the story is incredibly bland and unexciting and most of the characters you meet are devoid of personality. In essence, the game is unpolished and truthfully not worth the time investment. It is sad, because the pirate setting seemed interesting, the voice acting is remarkably good at times, and even the music (though repetitive) is enjoyable. The idea of scourging for hidden treasures, finding legendary artifacts and the different ways to buid your character are great... but in the end never really amount to anything. If you enjoyed the first one, you will probably like or at least tolerate this game. But having so many incredible RPG jewels out there, Risen 2 just isn't worth the effort. Ultimately, you can enjoy this game and it does have its moments, but only if you keep your expectations low.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2016
Product received for free
												With an expanded setting, a fresh story and characters as well as an all-new technical foundation, Risen 2 expands on the success of this popular RPG franchise. Set several years after the end of Risen, the game drops players into a cataclysmic world where raging titans have devastated the planet and pushed humanity to the brink of existence. Subsequently, monstrous creatures have risen from the watery depths of the sea and their attacks have brought all seafaring to a grinding halt. The hero, now a member of the Inquisition, is sent out to find out how to stop the chaos caused by these creatures from the deep. His quest begins with rumors that the pirates who frequent the southern islands are the only ones who know a way to get rid of the creatures once and for all and end their reign of terror.With an all-new pirate-based theme, Risen 2: Dark Waters aims to combine the most loved classic RPG gameplay mechanics of the original Risen with a fresh theme and setting on a huge variety of themed island locales. Risen 2: Dark Waters maintains the most immersive features of the original Risen, with multiple approaches to every challenge allowing players to shape the game world based on their own decisions. These choices will serve to unlock new paths, features and additional skills for the character.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												A complete turnaround from Risen 1, and I mean that quite literally. The first half of Risen 1 was pretty good, and the second half was obnoxious tedium. In Risen 2, the first half is obnoxious tedium, and the second half is pretty good.I can certainly understand how that might be a turnoff for many, and I can hardly blame them. Risen 2 doesn't get off to a great start, spending the first half of the game locked into a fairly linear storyline that doesn't hand out nearly enough gold or experience to become even remotely competent at anything, which forced me to pause the story a few times to wander around the jungle looking for loot and wildlife to kill, which was difficult considering that while the maps are extremely detailed to the point where I could almost always find a few nooks and crannies I hadn't noticed before, for most of the game nothing respawns so new sources of experience become increasingly hard to come by. Plus for this section of the game, your leveling path is completely restricted to whatever trainers are on hand, which made me wonder more than once why they even bothered with RPG mechanics if they clearly had their own idea as to how I was supposed to be building my character.However, once you reach what I think was about the halfway point (or at least it felt that way, might've just been the first act), you're finally given control of your own ship and can explore the various islands with pretty much total freedom, at which point the game really opens up. It becomes much easier to find the relevant skill tutors, monsters begin respawning (in small ammounts) when you travel between islands, the pacing overall just becomes better, and by then you've started to get the skills needed to not make the combat completely unbearable.And yes, the combat sucks. It's a notable improvement over Risen 1, where I turned on God Mode two-thirds of the way in because the game had devolved into a monotonous dungeon crawl at that point and the combat was clunky as hell and was deeply in love with stunlocks. Risen 2 is still deeply in love with stunlocks, but the combat is notably more responsive this time around so I made it about 90% of the way through before cheating, because ♥♥♥♥ed if I'm going to spend another dozen deaths trying to out-stunlock a giant spider with no pauses in its attack routine when the game arbitrarily decided my follower can't come with for this section.One final note I would make is that I'm glad Risen 3 has a new protagonist, because the Nameless Hero of the first two games is a complete turd of a human being. His every line of dialogue exhibits the personality of a man with absolutely no sense of respect, no principles, and no interest in the feelings of others beyond what can profit him in the short term. I'm pretty sure he's meant to be a blank slate for the player to project on, but if that's so the developers have a pretty low opinion of their audience. Sharing a headspace with this jerk for the 30+ hours it took to beat this game really made me want to see him thrown to the wolves so he could learn a bit of humility.(Oh, final-final note: about a third of the achievements in this game are bugged, don't waste your energy trying for 100% completion in that respect.)

Posted: September 1, 2015
												I bought this game and DLC on sale. Because i played Risen and read the bad reviews, i was hesitant to try it, but i was positively surprised. Imo, this game is better than Risen 1.I assumed my old save would be used together with my backstory, but this was not the case. I also seem to have lost an eye.In the beginning it was confusing, because the story tells i joined the inquisition, while i joined the bandits previously. If they had a story to back this up, i would have accepted it, but now they just assumed i chose to go with those arrogant p r i c k s.My review on Risen 1 would be a bit the same on this game.  Enemies are still overpowerd. While you start from scratch, enemies are fully skilled. People with muskets do overpowerd damage, wether it is ranged or just stabbing you when you're close. Upgrading skills isreally expensive. Barely any gear you can buy, which almost makes no difference, other than how you look. Quite disappointing. It is really the skills you invest in that makes the difference in how good you are at something.If there is an option to dress your char, i would like to take advantage of that, but the gear i liked did not have stats :( Unforunately, the ship cannot be used manually and/or upgraded, that would have been cool. You barely have any crewmembers.I like the fact you can now play with  a companion early in the game. Your compation knows every skill, so i often used them as a tank. Again, i liked the story.I would recommend the game contrary to Risen 1.A detailed story will be written later on.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												First I want to say that I LOVED Gothic 3 and really liked Risen but I cannot give Risen 2 a thumbs up as it is mediocre at best.The first reason being that the level of freedom seems to get cut in half with each new Gothic game (because this is essentially Gothic 5).  Gothic 3's level of freedom & choice was incredible and was the reason I dropped well over 160 hrs on it, Risen 2's only real choice is Voodoo or combat. Further to this is the ability to KILL.  Gothic 3 you could kill just about everyone, Risen 2 let's you kill NO ONE outside of normal enemies.  The best you can do in Risen 2 is knock them out BUT you CANNOT loot them and another NPC will quickly get them back on their feet then they will INSTANTLY be back at full health then go back to whatever they were doing with only a litttle "offended" message that shows, the consequence of which im yet to figure out. Next is the one choice you do get:  Voodoo or sword/guns, the former being fun but mostly useless, especially if you don't cheat.  Voodoo is pretty pathetic, it helps with a a handfull of story parts but for combat it's detrimental.  Sure you can possess enemies to fight eachother but that deprives you of precious Glory points and on NPCs it's a midly fun yet brief distraction at best.  Further to that it's almost entirely useless until it's leveled up which again, unless you cheat, won't be till later in the game.In a game where the combat is so unforgiving, especially ealry on, this choice essentially becomes: Swords/gun OR get your♥♥♥♥♥handed to you over and over.Overall the game felt rushed and, compared to Pirahna Bytes earlier offerings, terribly restricting.  The one bright spot was the gnome companion and his cute potty mouth.Pay no more than $5.

They could have done the exact same thing with the second game and it would have been a lot of fun but the only thing I can think of is that they had big ideas on a little budget and it just didn't work out.  There's a lot of better games out there to spend your money on - even at the reduced price.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												This game is an RPG in a semi-open world. You are a member of the inquisition, going undercover with pirates. The game starts out alright, It has impressive graphics, the voice acting isn't bad, some nice background music and sounds and a storyline that is understood quickly, but has some depth as well.It is during the game that I found out the game mechanics have been poorly chosen and implemented. The game doesn't give you any information about the keys needed for certain actions. For example, a double tap on a movement key (WASD) will makes the character role. With the character progressing, you can learn certain combat tecniques, such as kicking. Again, the game forgets to learn you the keys to do so (hold defensive position with right mouse buttion and then press jump key). It doesn't let you practice these abilities, nor seem some of them broken, like parry.In the end, combat results in spamming the left mouse button, interrupted by healing yourself. After a few hours, this gets so frustating, you will rage quit. Too bad, the game mechanics are so bad, because the game does show potential.

												sadly, this game was not as good as the first Risen. still good... but it has a lot of flaws. first of all, they kept main characters and plot, while moving from a sword-and-sorcery setting to one with guns and cannon, and moved to a carribean pirate aesthetic that really does not fit the feel of the previous game. second, the theme of the game is 'pirate', but a lot of that feels forced, like a checklist of tropes. there is no real 'choice', merely a rollercoaster. the only decision point worth noting is if you want to train voodoo or not. aside from that the game is also a bit buggy at times, and got stuck in the middle of the final bossfight. good overall, but it has its flaws. also, the skill system in this one is crap.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												Throwing in with a Piranha Bytes title, at the best of times, is a bit of a crap shoot.  Their games have been plagued from the start with programming issues and frustrating gameplay (like enemies that can just repeat-charge you to death), and yet the stories are consistently engaging, the worlds large and accessible, and the variety of progression rich.Risen improved SOMEWHAT on the poor combat model of the Gothic franchise and Risen 2 is even more polished.  Taken by itself, it is probably the most beautiful and professional game Piranha Bytes has produced to date (Risen 3 is due out soon) and it's genuinely fun to play.  Skills are extremely varied, from having your own parrot/monkey to do your bidding to various attacks to using guns, rifles and even voodoo; Risen 2 really throws a lot of gameplay options at you and surprisingly doesn't screw up any of them.  My biggest complaint was that if you choose rifles over voodoo there isn't really much in the way of skill progression available, but that's a minor issue.So to summarize, the game has pleasing visuals, solid gameplay and an interesting story that will take you to multiple islands and require much exploration and adventure to complete.  If you enjoyed Assassin's Creed: Black Flag for the setting you will likely enjoy this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												this is a review based on my first 30 hours of play. about 10 or so of that was a seperate playthrough, because i restarted in order to better allocate my xp and cash. i am far more impressed with this game than i thought i would be. so far, i have not experienced a single crash, or gamebreaking bug. performance on my above average pc (amd 8350 @ 4.81 ghz, 16 gb ram, amd 6970 oc'd) i experience some sub-30 fps at times with all settings maxed, but it remains playable at all times, and framerates are around or over 60 most of the time. and not one cdt or anything of the sort. if it does happen, i would most likely suspect a system bug, not the game code at this point. solid game.     the rpg elements are true rpg quality, with character progression direction being entirely up to the player, progression speed balanced about right (not too slow or too fast, both of which can ruin the overall game experience), and the progression mechanisms partially built right in to the environment. weapon availablilty depends on location and certain choices you make in the story. you can't just expect to max this character out over the course of the game, i very much doubt based on the arc so far, as well as the increasing requirements vs the limited ability to achieve those requirements.     there are numerous weapons, each attached to a skill. clothing is another high mark in this game. in all cases, the crap you start out with looks average at best, but as you gain fame and money, and reach new destinations, the clothing and weapons available get better and better, and have a high standard of quality when you see them on your character in the game.      every bit of dialogue is voice acted, and character models remain animated during voice interactions. alot of detail went in to building the environments as well, and each location, while sometimes similar to eachother to say the least, is a pleasant experience to look at.  the lockpicking minigame is the best execution of a lockpick minigame in any rpg i have played with such a mechanic. how many ♥♥♥♥ing lockpicks does a real lockpicker break, anyway lol. zero, that's how many. good choice on this, pirahna bites. i mean it.       what else can be said... collectibles are plentiful enough, shoplifting only earns you a fight instead of permanently ruining your relations with an entire town (here's looking at you bethesda), there are multiple ways to do many things in the game, the locations are large and plentiful... this is a top tier game in my book.      is it perfect? of course not. also, while plenty large enough for my tastes (and i do prefer a whole lot of world to explore), it is probably smaller in content than a bethesda masterpiece, but this game actually does alot of things better. think of it as... more focused. and it is still huge. you can't train a little monkey to steal for you in skyrim, or throw a parrot at your enemies face, or salt in their eyes, or breathe fire with a bottle of rum. maybe with mods, but you see my point probably. alot of variety and creativity are present.      i will add these notes: i use an xbox one controller, i play on easy (i tried medium but it was just too hard to be fun for me, though i may bump it back up if it gets TOO easy), i play on a smallish monitor but the game looks great at this resolution,  i am impressed with this game, and heartily recommend it to any fan of pirates, rpg or even a not-bad action game. 8.8 out of 10.edit: after completing this game, im lowering my rating a bit. still a great game, but it was a little short, and a little rushed at the end. what seemed like half way turned out to be 3/4, leaving me a little disappointed. so 7.5/10 after completion. solid and worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Not A Worthy SequelIf you were a big fan of Risen and looking for more of the same with Risen 2 you're going to be disappointed. While there are plenty of locations to explore, treasure to find, NPCs to interact with and enemies to slay, the core gameplay mechanics revolving around combat have taken several steps backwards. Gone is the fluid and intuitive combat that Risen boasted, where a combination of player skill, character stats and gear met that allowed one to tackle the most dangerous enemies in the game from the start if they had the skill and timing to back it up. Melee combat was very much like Gothic 1/2 or Dark Souls 1 in that way. You also had magic and ranged weaponry which were both highly effective if one desired that approach.Risen 2 does away with skill-based melee combat, featuring stilted, often broken animations and combat reduced to you and your foe hacking away at one another until one dies with a token dodge thrown in here or there. Magic is gutted and beyond worthless, and ranged weapons (guns) are extremely powerful to the point of trivializing the entire game.That said, if you're willing to overlook the atrocious downgrade combat has taken and want to see how the story plays out, it's worth a playthrough; but keep your expectations low.Final Score - 6.5/10

												I had no expectations going in, and I ended up LOVING this game.  Not a lot of pirate themed games out there, and certainly not a lot of pirate RPG's. content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												I'll start with some gripes...I've searched far and wide for ways to make the game function more smoothly; I have 8GB of ram and a decent processor, but fiddling with the settings hasn't helped much. Aside from some annoying deaths near the beginning though, the cutscenes are fine, the atmosphere is beautiful, and the sound is, suprisingly enough, not disappoining, even though Kai Rosenkranz didn't return as composer.Some pluses! As stated earlier, the music is great, and keeps in the spirit of the first title despite a change of composers. I liked the environments near the beginning a lot more than those in the first game, particularly the blazing city backdropped against a nice, gloomy, rainy, dark little fort. The first thing I look for in a game on Steam, even before solid gameplay previews and managable system requirements, is solid localization. Russian and English voices and subtitles are nearly a requirement, and messing around in German and Polish is fun. This game has all of those, while a lot of popular titles seem to skimp on this.I think this has been on sale at least twice for something absurd like 15-20$ for all three Risen titles with all DLC, so if it goes on sale again, buy the damned thing.

												Now let me say this first; everyone has there own personal opinion, some people like things that others don't, and this is one of them.now that I got that out, let's get to the review. Risen 2: Dark waters is not the best RPG out there, but it's not the worst. I originally thought the game was crap because of what I heard from reviewers. But when I tryed out the demo I was suprised. the bad game mechanics I heard of seamed normal to me, they were like every other RPG game i've played before, and the fact that you pay gold to learn a new skill, was like when you pay gold to upgrade a skill in skyrim. the animations are not the best, but I don't mind because they make me laugh. the story was enjoyable, personaly I got sucked into it. the character models are the same from time to time but I think thats funny; just meeting someone in one island and sailing over to a diffrent one, and finding that person again on the island just with diffrent clothes and maybe a diffrent actor. and in the game you can use voodoo magic, and at times I just feel like a god seeing people kill each other, or scared of me because I used voodoo on one of them. But that dose'nt mean this game is the greatest of all time, there are things I dont like. One of the things I had a problem with was the fact that you could'nt sail your ship like in assassins creed 4, I was hoping for that. But instead your ship is a fast travel to diffrent islands. as well as the fact I am not allowed to swim in the game made me a bit upset. and finally, the fact that I could'nt interact with the world like how you could in the first risen.but like I said it's not a bad game, there was just stuff they did'nt add that could have made it a great game, for everyone who loves rpgs like skyrim or witcher.  but like I said it's not badMy personal score would be7/10

content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												Alright, here goes (A few spoilers)...CONS:-This game REEKS of poor design choices. The combat is the clunkiest I've ever seen in any game ever (even worse than the original Risen which was also pretty awful).-The difficulty curve starts off as a brick wall that turns into a damn cliff once you get over it (as in, it's hard as balls at first, then it becomes laughably easy).-The first "real" boss at the Earth Temple is interesting but then every other boss in the game save for the second to last (which uses the EXACT same mechanics as the Earth Temple boss) is just standard swordfights.-There are exactly two characters that are even remotely memorable throughout the game, and they both either die after the first boss or are as useless as voodoo.-Oh, and Voodoo is useless except for the points where it's shoehorned into the plot and you have to learn it and use it from time to time.-Money is damn near impossible to come by early on, and any time you DO have money you have to throw it at a skill trainer to learn the basic freaking skill set for your desired weapon(s) because SOMEHOW the player character forgot literally -EVERYTHING between the first game and this one.-Speaking of... after a certain point money starts piling up all at once. During the first 3/4 of the game you're poor as dirt, and then during the last 1/4 of the game you've got a minimum of 10k gold unless you specifically buy EVERY skill, period.-What the hell were the developers doing switching from a fantasy RPG to a ♥♥♥♥ing Pirate RPG?-There's no real feeling of your character's growth - you just buy new gear and more skills every now and then when you can afford them. You don't get that feeling of "Holy crap these enemies used to be so tough but now I'm oneshotting them! I'm so badass!" it's more like, "Ugh, these things again. It's a good thing I got this new sword so I can kick the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of it slightly quicker."-There are no stats. Your health is capped at 100 with no way of increasing it. You cannot increase your character's strength as a fighter, you can only increase your base "Blade" ability and then beyond that buy more blade-related skills. You choose from slashing, piercing, and thrown weapons (sabre, rapier, and spear/throwing daggers, respectively), and pistols, muskets, and shotguns.Magic was completely removed in favor of Voodoo; which, yeah, it fits the whole "Pirates of the Carribbean" thing they've got going here, but it's still pretty dumb - especially how they wrote it off as "The Inquisition (who, by the way, you joined up with between games regardless of which faction you sided with in the first game) banished all mages because they didn't stop the Inquisition from ♥♥♥♥ing up in the first game."PROS:The story and world are interesting.It's fairly lengthy. Not as long as the previous game, but not short as 90% of AAA titles out there.Some other things which I honestly can't describe (see below).Now, all that being said I actually have to recommend this game, just not at full price. Wait 'til it's on sale, or better yet wait 'til the collection is on sale and you can get the first and second game for just shy of $10 like I did. I don't know what it is about this game and its predecessor, but the things they do right they do EXTREMELY right; it's just that the things they do wrong they do really, really, REALLY wrong, so it averages out into a decently albeit mediocre game....seriously though who the hell changes themes like that? That'd be like if the next Elder Scrolls game was about pirates, or if the next CoD was about Vietnam war protests, or if Half Life 3 ended up being a third person fantasy RPG like the first Risen.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												If I had one complaint for Risen 2 is that it's a bad Pirhana Byte game. I'm not someone who complains about a game being too casualized or too easy, but I can't ignore how many ways Risen 2 is a step back from Risen 1.That being said, I can still admire Risen 2 as a good game. Maybe someone who doesn't like the style of Gothic 1/2 and Risen 1 would still enjoy the game. The power of the game's theme carries it far, and if you want a light-hearted, challenging pirate game then Risen 2 is a great choice.(Just don't expect ship-battles.)If you have played Risen 1, you MUST play this game on Hard mode (even if you played the first game on Easy, like myself). Even at that setting you'll probably get by with far fewer deaths than the first game.If you haven't played Risen 1, I wouldn't recommend Risen 2 as an entry into the Gothic games. It's an accessible title for newcommers, yes, but the game doesn't have that freeform sense of discovery, replayability and challenge which makes PB games what they are known for. It wouldn't prepare you to play the other games.Arr Role To Play the Game (ARPG)If Risen 1 was centered on the mage role with Rune Magic, then Risen 2 is focused on a Thief/Pirate character. The difference is R1 allowed you to be more liberal with your playstyle and offered you multiple paths to make you curious to play the game again. R2 feels tailored to a specific playthrough.Swords, Guns and Thievery are what you will want to specialize in to get the most out of the game. Voodoo is far too strict/limiting to use in the main game and you'd be better off not crafting items of any kind and be better off looting what you can find. Alchemy, Distillery, Smithing and animal trading are useless fluff for immersion. Even if you don't care of replaying the same playstyle over again, then you'll find little to offer a second playthrough. There is a fork in the road to make the game feel like it's made for two runs. In reality, however, it's all a ruse. For one, if you're someone like me, you'll side with what you think is the good/right faction. The benefit of R1 was that the Don's men and the Order had both positive and negative qualities, making it unable to say who were the good guys. In R2, the natives are obviously portrayed as the underdog with little to no faults. Second, the branching paths connect together sooner than they part. They only shape how you go through the scenario, which feels way too linear to make you feel like you're accomplishing anything. (For example, you can't just make voodoo dolls of anyone to figure out how to solve a problem.)My recommendation is to make a Pirate-themed character, side with the natives for the Voodoo to change things up a little bit for the rest of the game--you don't even need to invest in the skill--and you'll get an enjoyable 25 to 30 hours of an experience. (Especially if you get the DLC.)Streamlined CombatUnlike other fans, I am actually okay with the new format for the control scheme. It plays similar enough to Risen 1 that it doesn't feel out of place--instead of side-stepping we have Witcher 2 style rolling and we also have Demons' Souls memory of your inputs. However, it's far from being perfect. The problem is actually that PB didn't make the controls simple enough, and the combat animations are too janky to read properly.On an X1 controller, you use X for attack (power-attack, riposte, etc.), Y for kick, jump and dodge, LT for parrying (the block) and RT for using a projectile weapon. When you hold down the LT button, you lock on to the nearest enemy and you can do a real parry and riposte (clicking X then Y simaltaneously). B and A are not used in combat. At all.This becomes a problem when you want to dodge rather than kick. Had they maped it to another button then you'd never have the problem of kicking by accident when the enemy circle-strafes your camera in the forward direction. And because you get a different control when holding LT for Y, then I don't see why they didn't do the Assassin's Creed layout of mapping buttons over one another. Switching them out with the LT.If that's too technical, the problem is they mapped way too many actions to one button when they have a better alternative, overlaying the buttons with a way to switch between them. It causes problems because some actions are based on where you are moving and how the camera moves. Another change I would suggest is implementing a Dark Souls stamina meter. It would counter-act spaming the dodge-roll button or make your attacks carry more weight in every battle. That would be one innovation I'd like to see.Speaking of abusing missing frames, the other major problem with R2 are the animations. Some enemies are too inconsistent to know when to strike in order to counter their attack, so you're better off dodging than parrying. Also, the block, for example, will sometimes block some enemies but refuse to block other attacks (like the Warthog). It's not clear what is acceptable and what is not from the animations shown. You simply won't know until you try, which I don't think is all that great.Despite these problems, I think the combat is an improvement; it's simpler, which makes each encounter full of tension with every strike you make. So long as you get over that inconsistency curve.(Oh, and the boss fights still suck. Not surprised.)Is Less More or Is More Less?The biggest change from R1 to R2 is the exploration. Instead of being on one landmass with multiple entrances/exits and shaping how you traverse the island from the story's progression, you are exploring about 10 islands (with DLCs included) of a similar size.It's hard to tell whether every major island is bigger or smaller than R1's location because the enemy mobs are much less of a problem than Risen 1. That change is definitely something I like as I found Ch 2 to 4 tedious from the enemy mobs. As a result of the variety of the islands, and the non-linear manner of the game, the islands sometimes lack an identity. Only a few have major differences than being a tropical beach for colonization.But because you're always finding something new to explore you will want to continue playing. The game has some Legendary items to give you permanent stat boosts and secret crew members to accompany you to make the exploration worthwhile. The best thing to do when arriving on an island is to ignore the settlements and go wander on your own--you'll get a lot more done that way.The worst change in exploration, however, is how much they've neutered the sense of exploration. Climbing is no longer as free to the player as in R1; dungeon crawling isn't about spatial awareness to traps or secret pathways; and exploring the environment to shortcuts doesn't feel as rewarding as before.Some might argue that it's due to consoles--especially the unnecessary QTEs--but Risen 1 was on the 360, even in a crappy state they didn't implement these changes. So why they limited the game this way makes no sense.Something To Be Found Beneath the GrimeIf it seems like I'm bashing Risen 2 a lot more than prasing its improvements, that's because there is a gem of a game to be found underneath the rough edges. The lore continues on from Risen 1 in some interesting ways, the characters you come across are more memorable, and even the horrible voice-acting and writing continue to have an amusing charm.Instead of being a grim, hardcore Pirate RPG, we have a light-hearted, self-aware yet still challenging Pirate game that has a lot more to enjoy than to lament on its shortcomings. At some point you should consider playing this game for fun.

												A Really nice RPG, with a really nice setting. The characters are a lot of fun to listen to, and some of the dialogue has had me in hysterics. Ive read some things about the combat being poor but in my opinion it isnt all that bad, its not great but its no worse than say Skyrims or The Witchers. I'm not that far into it, but so far its been very enjoyable. Lots of exploration of intresting environments, looting and lots of killing turkeys for chicken (yes im serious). One thing to note is that its hard to gain skills and level up your character, unlike in most modern RPGs where you level up and gain skills from doing things over time (like in Bethseda games) in this and Risen 1, skills cost gold and  'glory' (both of which you need a LOT of) to level up your attributes, talents and skills etc. So be prepared to sink a hell of lot of time in just building your character to be able to defeat harder foes.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												I started Risen 2 straight after completing the original Risen, which I greatly enjoyed. First off I'd like to point out that Risen 2 has made some vast improvements in certain areas: the graphics, layout, fast travel and I haven’t got stuck in a jump animation once (Which was a regular occurrence in the original) Along with a range of other things.But despite all of the improvements that have been made, one thing lets this game down for me. The combat. In Risen 1, the combat was difficult, but once you got the hang of each type of enemy it was a difficult but rewarding system. Risen 2 handles human combat (player vs human AI) well and is a little reminiscent of Risen 1 (Maybe even a little better) But the animal combat (Player vs anything non-humanoid) is painful. There's no better way to describe it, you cannot block or interrupt animals attacks, you're forced to either dodge and bunny hop around like crazy or just burn through health items  simply to stay alive. I really would like to recommend this game, but it's just not enjoyable having to fight packs of wild boar while getting rammed repeatedly by whichever one you’re not currently dodging.I would suggest you try Risen 1, which has its own flaws, but I still found significantly more enjoyable than this.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												Итак, я продолжаю свой цикл обзоров на игры серии Risen. Обзор на Risen: http://steamcommunity.com/id/thgttg_marvin/recommended/40300Обзор на Risen 3: http://steamcommunity.com//id/thgttg_marvin/recommended/249230Risen 2: Dark Waters является почти прямым продолжением оригинала.Сюжет продолжает историю Безымянного Героя, который за неизвестное время успел отрастить волосы, бороду, потерять глаз и обзавестись харизмой. После событий первой части, в которой  Герой пленил Огненного Титана, человечество оказалось на грани существования. Целью Безымянного стал один из Лордов Титанов - Мара, которая, при помощи осьминого-подобного существа Кракена, потихоньку уничтожает корабли Инквизиции. Первой задачей ГГ становится проникновение в ряды пиратов, у которых есть оружие для борьбы с Марой. Помогает ему в этом Бэтти - бывшая владелица трактира на Фаранге и дочь капитана Стальная Борода, к которому и направляется наш герой. Мир игры очень сильно изменился. На замену Мечу, Луку и Щиту пришли Шпаги, Сабли и Пистолеты.  Такой резкий переход из одной эпохи в другую почти никак не объясняется... Первые 2-3 часа могут показаться очень скучными. Во первых это из-за того, что вас держат в рамках сюжета, который не позволит вам покинуть остров, пока вы не выполните все необходимые задания, а во вторых - из-за малого количества самих заданий... Однако после второй локации игра начинает расцветать.Игра заметно прибавила в масштабе. Вместо одного острова теперь целый Архипелаг, поделённый на островные и береговые локации. Между ними вы можете перемещаться совершенно свободно с помощью своего личного корабля. Плавать на нём, как в AC4: Black Flag, вам не дадут, но это на само деле не нужно, Risen - игра не про часовое стояние за штурвалом. В каждой локации вас всё также ждёт море квестов, которые стали ещё интереснее. В пример я могу привести квест, в котором нужно помочь кандидату стать вождём и сюжетный отрывок на острове Воров, в котором вам придётся встретить мирное поселение Карлов (я знаю, что в Risen 2 они называются своим оригинальным названием "Гномы", но "Карлы" мне привычнее...). Интерес к квестам прежде всего вызывает появившийся в игре Юмор, например в выше названном квесте с новым вождём, по заданию нужно будет вселиться в тело одного из кандидатов и ответить на вопросы Вождя. На вопрос "Где тебя так долго не было?" Герой отвечает "Нужно было отлить сходить!", что вызвало у Вождя недоумение.В геймплее игры произошли некоторые изменения. Из-за них игра стала заметно проще, чем должна быть, но это не критично. Изменения коснулись прежде всего Ролевой и Боевой систем. В ролевой системе теперь не нужно качать Очки Обучения с каждым новым уровнем. За выполнение квестов и убийство различной мерзости вам начисляют Очки Славы, которые вы вольны потратить на любую из 5 веток развития: Холодное оружие, Огнестрел, Выносливость (прокачка здоровья), Ловкость (воровство и красноречие) и Вуду - новый вид магии, который пришёл на замену Кристальной магии из первой игры (по сюжету, после Фаранги кристальная магия стала "вне закона"). Учителя тут также остались но теперь их задачей стало обучение различным "особым" навыкам. Ещё была улучшена система взлома и в не самую лучшую сторону изменена система торговли.В боевой системе появилась возможность использовать пистолеты или какой-либо из "грязных приёмов". Комбинации ударов сократили, теперь большинство битв проходятся простым "закликиванием" врагов, в то время как в первой игре нужно было постоянно использовать различные удары, чтобы убить врага. Автонаведение стало вести себя более адекватно, что меня искренне порадовало.Ещё из плюсов хотел бы отметить отличную постановку сюжетных сцен, чего только стоят сцены битвы с Титаном Земли и Кракеном, а так же  гибель Стальной Бороды и его последующее появление на острове Мертвецов.Из минусов же во первых хочется отметить отвратительный подход локализаторов к проекту. Описывать всю убогость перевода и озвучки я не буду, это надо увидеть и услышать самому...Из других: запуск игры на Восьмерке при помощи танцев с бубном, всё так же малое количество моделей персонажей, однотипные корабли, крохотные посёлки с максимум 10-ю жителями и уже отмеченную систему торговли.Итоговая Оценка - 8/10 если смотреть на игру со всеми её минусами, и 10/10 если просто наслаждаться всё так же отличным миром, хорошим сюжетом, свободой действий и персонажами, включая Главного Героя.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												As player who finished all Gothic and Risen games I have to say I loved the game. At first I did not liked it, and thought fighting system is bad, but as I was playing longer opposite showed to be true. I have found melee tactitcs almost for all enemy types. And only melee skill I learnt for most of the game was kick, I was playing as woodoo thief. When I read reviews that they say you have to spam mouse 1 clicking in melee I have to feel bad about them because spamming is viable only in realy rare ocassions. Agaisnt some enemies works blocking, agaisnt some not (there are even some enemies which you can't block, sadly one of them is enemy where they are trying to learn you blocking via tips :-) ). When blocking fails, try kicking or dodging. And so on. You have to use your brain, see enemies patterns and use them agaisnt them. And even when you don't like it, there is other way to enjoy the game. You can use firearms, by joing right faction. And this si lots of fun as well, and it is way easier. Another contributin to fighting in general are dirty tricks, you can throw sand/salt to enemy eyes, so you get free hit, if done succesfully. Later you can even use parrot to distract your enemies for longer periods of time. Woodoo gives you adventage in fight as well, if you choose woodoo instead of firearms. Of course as in most RPG game, luring out enemies one by one is the way to go most of the time. Another thing I liked about the game was, that  it made laught many, many times. Especially some mission fullfiled using woodoo were amazing. Another good thing is that you have companion of your choice availabe due to most of the game, which makes fighting easier as well. Story was  somehow predicitble, but still fun. I haven't encountered any bugs, except one minigame seemed to be as hard on normal as on hard (on easy it was easier), but maybe it was not bug. And some achievments does not unlock. One complain I will have about the game is that some skills seemed to be underused. For example great idea with trained monkey. Yes it pays for itself, but could be used way more during the game. Weapon smithing and gun smithing seemed to be pretty much useless, taking into account price of recepies and materials, with exception with use to forge legendary weapons. Another complain will be that there was no normal fighting teacher on the second island, or at least I did not  found him. As for the replaybility, you can play it once using woodoo, and once using fire arms.  Solution to some quest (mainly main story quest) will be different. And fighting is different as well. I wil reccomend RIsen 2 to all gothic fans, because as one of them I love it.

												The first Risen was phenomenal. This one started out just as great... then somewhere into the story I started questioning my life decisions (literally). Gone is the overall sense that you're working towards something big or about to stumble upon a huge discovery like in the first game. Gone is the continuity and sense of connection with the characters (I think the sudden transition from being a hero of an island to a being a nameless pirate was too much for me). content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												A great RPG/Adventure game. The first 2/3 of the game I'd say I preferred the original, but towards the end I was all about #2 (I also haven't played Risen in a couple of years so my memory of it is a little foggy). I do like how Risen was more like Gothic overall, and Risen is definitely more challening than #2.. There were times it felt easy for this kind of game (I played it all the way through on Medium except I turned it on easy during the annoying target practice part). Risen 2 does have some pretty good graphics, but nothing mind blowing. There are also some graphical glitches from time to time, but nothing major. It doesn't run as smooth as the first Risen either. I also do prefer the combat in Risen, but after unlocking a ton of skills the gameplay in Risen 2 does get better and better as you go. The story also gets better the further it got along, but I also think that Risen and the Gothic games I played are the same in that way.  Well, in the Risen and Gothic games everything just seems to get better and better. They're all really fun games that put a big emphasis on exploring. Exploration is the main ingredient, and Risen 2 gives you lots of area to explore. It's not a huge game, but it is big. The soundtrack is pretty solid, too. The voice acting is good most of the time. Some of the dialogue is fun. Most of it is kind of what you'd expect in a RPG game like this, but the pirate theme adds some rough dialogue that can be amusing. When the game was all said and done I felt I had enough, but I really enjoyed my time with Risen 2. It's an underrated game, for sure. 8/10

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												I'm a fan of pirate scenarios and naval combat.  Unfortunately, despite carrying that theme, Risen 2 is stylized and plays like an Elder Scrolls Lite title, but without the support of the absurdity of ES modding communities to provide and/or refine all the needed elements.The basis of the game is "Yay Pirates" combat, which while it can occassionally be entertaining, is often nothing more than frustrating due to the mechanics.  Melee combat has two modes: attack and die.  If you block on a melee character, you're awful and need to reevaluate your life choices.  Blocking is purely useful to ranged characters, because on melee, blocking an enemy attack staggerlocks you, which causes you to delay before being able to counterattack, allowing the enemy to hit you again to interrupt your counterattack, or to blockbreak you.  You can tumble away though, allowing it to be viable to ranged combat.  The problem with ranged combat though is the limited resource of bullets.  Bullets are fairly rare, and must be conserved for boss battles and duels, because entering into melee combat in those situations is suicidal (mostly due to bugs: bosses can't be staggerlocked, you can, so you lose in a melee slugfest), but going ranged trivializes these encounters.  Easiest example?  The very first "challenge" duel in the tutorial area: if you melee him, he outdamages you, staggerlocks you and you lose.  That fight is designed for you to lose, give up and come back later when you're on his level (he hits ~4x as hard as you do at low levels).  But if you block, tumble back and hit him with a pistol shot, then kite until he catches you, rinse and repeat?  You can complete the fight without getting hit.The skill trees, while entertaining in theory, are plagued by a very clear "Best path", due to the alternatives not being viable. For example, pursuing the Monkey skill requires you to forgo combat specs (making the game harder), but the Monkey is awful, so there's no reason to suffer through a path with no benefits for the first half of the game, when the big payoff is a complete letdown.The game also lacks naval combat, so it's not truly a Pirate game.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2014
												Unimaginative and tiresome RPG that has you running back and forth in the traditional style, doing chores for unimportant people in an effort to build up enough experience points to buy your way out of the opening scenario, which sucks.  You'll end up having to play the opening chapter several times just to avoid making a few easy mistakes which prevent you from getting past a bottleneck, thus fencing off the rest of the game from you.  Unless you can do enough great deeds to convince the pirate captain to take you with him, you might as well just give up, and it really does all hinge around that.  Tip: don't introduce yourtself to the pirate captain until you have finished all the quests in chapter one, or you will lose the use of his daughter as a co-fighter.  Or just blast your way through and learn this for yourself and have to play the first chapter several times over to get it right.  It's just too dull to bear repeat plays.More bottlenecks await, they've chosen that path for this second instalment.  I find myself pecking at this game from time to time as slight enthusiasm returns.  There's a mild humour, but nothing you'd miss if it wasn't there.  Some bugs too, preventing you from completing a couple of quests at least.  Voodoo pirates might make slick viewing in family adventure films (a la Walt Disney) but in games like this, where people play in their own private world, they just don't roll like they ought to.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												I tried to stick with this game but I really just can't. Risen 2 had a lot of potential with the pirate theme but ended up tripping all over itself trying to tie everything in together. the controls are the biggest issue here. They're the worst RPG controls I've ever experienced. Your character moves as if he is locked on a grid and he reacts poorly to the keys most of the time (maybe its just me, I can be wrong here).The combat was disappointing, it had the premise of being a tactical swordplay type of game but ultimately timing is pointless when the enemies have unblockable attacks and are faster than you. What fun is an RPG game if you don't look forward to fighting? That means a good chunk of the game is already unenjoyable and lost due to this poorly designed system. Levelling up is a chore, thousands of gold and glory are required and you're barely rewarded for taking the difficult quests. The characters are flat along with the disappointing story. the loot is barely worth the time with the lack of variety. The graphics are quite outdated and tax low end computers badly despite the quality of the graphics (my low end machine barely gets 30fps with the bad graphics). The writing isn't that good as well, the humor can be funny but most of the time the jokes are shallow. The voice acting isn't exactly good either. Aside from the main characters the npcs sure sound half baked when they talk.I fear that the Risen franchise may be in too deep to redeem itself with failure after failure. 5/10. The game is painfully average and doesn't give any sense of accomplishment with its quests.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												This game sucks. Even for a 2010 title, the game mechanics and overall story are found lacking. The only few things that make this game even qualify for the RPG genre are the functions of Lockpicking, Smithing, and that it is single player. The dialogue options are incredibly basic, the tutorial time totals around 1.5 hrs, and the lack of being able to kill any non-hostile NPC's devalues the game. Instead, you can knock out an NPC (such as the Worker, who is unarmed) and they will crouch for about a minute before getting right back up. Similarly, when you try to assault the town guards, they quickly defeat you and you get back up, in additon to losing 50 'Honor' points. These aspects make the game feel very restrictive.The one decent thing about Risen 2 is its art and graphic design, which mostly applies to specific objects like the first ship you sail on. In terms of facial design and resolution, both are low.To be completely honest, I only ever finally installed it just to get the Steam Trading Cards it has.Edit: I've now beat the game, and still stand by everything I said three years ago. This is a low quality game- I now truly know that.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												As a huge fan of the Gothic series I was reasonably excited for when the first Risen game was announced. Although it was mostly just a copy of Gothic 2 and its gameplay systems I still very much enjoyed it. Risen 2 tries to innovate on that formula. And I am thankful for that, since it was getting a bit stale towards the end of the first game.Risen 2 is a bit of hard game to get into, even for a fan of the developer. You really need to put a few hours into the game to get it going, as it has a very slow start. I'd say that'd be once you're past the first island as a pirate (yes the game has multiple islands which you can sail to anytime you want once you've discovered them and once you get yourself a ship), but it does take a good 4-5 hours to get through that.The game's biggest problem is the combat system, it is just badly designed, while the previous Risen/Gothic games had no great combat systems either, they had a lot of different ways you could approach it. In Risen 2 you are much more limited for most of the game. You can use swords, muskets or voodoo to vanquish your enemies, however you only get access to the the latter two much later in the game and they are painfully underdeveloped. As a result you will mostly just try and melee your way out of everything, and the melee system is quite bad.Piranha Bytes did a fine job with world building in this game, and they made sure there are interesting quests here also. And once you're past the initial slog, the game just keeps getting better. And at a fine length of about 20-25 hours, you will most certainly leave satisfied if you can manage to get there.7½ / 10

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
												I would definetely reccomend Risen 2 Dark Waters. If you like playing role playing games (Skyrim, the witcher etc) like me, this is a must have. You have absolute freedom in this game, there are many islands and locations to explore and there are a lot of side-quests and other fun stuff to do. The main story focusses on pirates, but there are a lot of things going on around it. You can recruit people for your ship, buy a monkey etc. The graphics are also stunning, even though at first i had to get used to the slightly different style of the graphics, i now absolutely love it. The detail in the towns and buildings is just incredible. You can play this game hours and hours without having the feeling there is nothing to do, it's incredible!There are however also some downsides which could have been better:1. The combat is basically the same through the whole game, it comes down to hitting, evading and hitting again with now and then an pistol move which has to be recharged. This can get very repetetive and boring after a while.2. There are some glitches in the game, it doesn't ruin the gaming experience but it can be annoying now and then.If you have any questions about Risen 2 or you don't know whether the money is worth it, i will gladly answer them or help you in any way!
