number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 22, 2014
												I'm quite impressed with this sequel to the highly enjoyable Risen.Not only have the graphics and controls been improved, but the feeling of freedom and exploration remain in tact. I'm not a huge fan of the pirate setting and quite honestly I prefered the more late medieval setting of the original, but it doesn't really hurt anything and provides an excuse to change up some of the mechanics like replacing crossbows with muskets and magic with voodoo.What I continue to like about this game and series is that if feels realistic overall, while providing fantasy elements in appropriate quantity that it still feels fantastic. Magic isn't blasted around like it's mundane, and strange creatures like giant crabs and ghouls will assault you between duals with vicious pirates or a hungry jaguar.The combat system still feels a bit rough, but it's an improvement over the last game. Musket blasts and sword slashes feel like they are hitting and making an impact, but there is still a level of random unavoidable damage from enemy attacks that can frustrate you during combat that feels a bit too fast at times and a bit too glitchy at other times. You will need to save often, because like the original Risen, you'll die from enemy encounters...a lot.Now of course the most important aspect of a RIsen game is the roleplaying element. So far, I'm happy to say that you'll be running errands, playing people against each other, and choosing factions and training paths as in the first Risen. Because it's a sequel and events were established in the first game, there at first appears to be less choice of your overall direction, but that fades away as the game continues. Allies are made and play a larger role in your adventures this time as well (although they are invincible and hiding behind them during encounters will almost feel like cheating). It does add the illusion of story driven set pieces in an otherwise extremely open-world type adventure.So far, my overall rating of Risen 2: Dark Waters♠♠♠♠♠Five aces of spades! If you want a beautifully crafted open world adventure on the high seas and tropical islands...Risen 2 will deliver!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Risen 2 follows the original Risen and Gothic 1&2 as entertaining and challenging 3rd person rpgs.  I enjoyed it about the same as Gothic 2 but with an ease of use not found in the Gothic games.  The controls have improved IMMENSELY since Gothic 1&2 and combat is more intriguing compared to Risen.  The story isn't the most engaging, but it is fun, including a few surprise moments.  The voice acting is good, but accompanying hand movements can be silly and repetitive.    I encountered some minor graphical glitches (swords not being in NPC's hands, for instance) but no major crashes.  The environmental graphics were quite a bit better than I expected.  The characters and their animations seem to be a slight step up from Risen.  The HUD is unobtrusive and allows for some sense of immersion.   Now, I am comparing it to Risen and Gothic 1&2 because of the setting, protaganist and system.  It is not an action RPG.  It is not Diablo, Skyrim  Choices can matter to how the quests resolve and the story progesses.  There is action and prompts for traps.  Combat isn't the easiest, either to use or to survive against the monsters until a few tricks are learned.  All in all, I recommend the game if you like RPGs or wish to try one.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												A good follow-up to the original.  It takes place a couple of years after Risen 1.  It was kinda wierd to go from a heavy medieval theme in Risen 1 to a heavy pirate theme in Risen 2, but I kind of liked it.My biggest problem in the first installment was the combat and the sticky focusing.  Sticky focus is gone, and it makes a HUGE difference in gameplay for PC users.  It's much easier to control and maneuver your character once you get used to it.  Dodge roll is your friend and incredibly powerful in it's defensive capability.  Once you get the timing and the angles you won't even bother with parry.At first I thought they pulled a 180 and made combat just as difficult as the first one but in a different way.  They took away a lot of the timed attacks and blocking that was notorious in Risen 1, and added what felt like a button mashing system for Risen 2.  Different style, same frustration.  Once you get a bit of Glory (XP) and put a few points into Blades you can get access to riposte and powerful riposte but I never bothered to build it past 6/10.  The real game changer was getting a bit of gear and access to muskets.  This made combat a LOT easier.  Dodge roll then musket shot, repeat.  There is also the addition of the companion system.  This allows you to take a companion with you for most of the game.  It's a huge help to have mobs focus on another npc or have a pack focus on you while they kill them off 1 by 1.  Overall I'd say this was an improvement in the combat system.Equipment is a lot better in the sense that, it felt you had a little bit of choice in what you could use, at least more than Risen 1.  I focused on Thief-skill, Musket, and Toughness items but you could just as easily build a more melee centric or voodoo based class.I feel that they improved the leveling and skill selection system as well.  Killing mobs, completing quests, etc gives you Glory.  Glory is spent to increase your main attributes: Blades, Firearms, Toughness, Cunning, and Voodoo.  Each of these Attributes affects 3 skills.  Talents that give you better abilities, both passive and active can be purchased with gold via trainers IF your main attribute is high enough.  So there's quite a bit of flexibility with character customization.Overall I really enjoyed this game.  More so than the original, but mainly because I didn't have to wait until the end of the game for combat to be easier and the addition of the companion system.  Definitely recommend this whether you enjoyed the first Risen or not.  It's a continuation of the first game but it can be played as a stand alone.

												Overall, a fun game if you like pirates and action/RPGs and don't mind giving it a few hours to start before the fun really sets in.Pros:-Be a pirate! Drink rum! Swashbuckle! Dig for buried treasure!-Environments are of a good size and allow for exploration-Variety of enemies from insects to jaguars to undead. Also PIRATES-AI companions offer some enrichment for combat and have unique personalities-Some customization for your character by choosing skills to focus on-Good variety of weapons and skills including several types of blades and guns, or even throw coconuts!-Persuade, pickpocket, lockpick, or even voodoo your way out of sticky situations if you train these skillsCons:-Slow to get started-No customization of character name/class/appearance-Combat can be awkward with lots of repeatedly pressing attack button-Skills are all quite expensive to purchase/train in and don't appear to be well scaled to the rate your attributes increase-HUD lacking, no stamina bar or minimap visible-Poor quality AI - allies get lost, enemies care if you steal but forget you if you walk a short distance and return.

												great RPG i know a lot of people hate this game but i really enjoyed it its pirate setting is awesome theres now firearms and voodoo and no more magic and the story and soundtrack is wonderful the graphics in this game are stunning not as good as other game like in the witcher 2 but still good and just like all PB games the voice acting is very well done and later on in the game you can get a ship a start your own crew each of your crew members have thier own abilities now the game isnt all good and i can see why a lot of people hate this game like when you start you cant kill anything and you will have almost no money not til after a while of playtime til you can learn voodoo or how to fire a gun and the combat feels off like not til later on in the game you can learn how to do more then just wacking away with the left mouse and but later when you get stronger it makes the combat better but you always feel like there isnt much you can do you and you dont really run a ship your ship is just a way to get from island to island and its not like you can sail the seas and raid other ships and this game isnt as hardcore as past PB games so it dose lose some of the things the things that made risen and the first 3 gothic games stand out so i would recommend this game only if your a fan of PB and can look past problems and enjoy it for what it is

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2014
												Risen 2 follows the original Risen and Gothic 1&2 as entertaining and challenging 3rd person rpgs.  I enjoyed it about the same as Gothic 2 but with an ease of use not found in the Gothic games.  The controls have improved IMMENSELY since Gothic 1&2 and combat is more intriguing compared to Risen.  The story isn't the most engaging, but it is fun, including a few surprise moments.  The voice acting is good, but accompanying hand movements can be silly and repetitive.    I encountered some minor graphical glitches (swords not being in NPC's hands, for instance) but no major crashes.  The environmental graphics were quite a bit better than I expected.  The characters and their animations seem to be a slight step up from Risen.  The HUD is unobtrusive and allows for some sense of immersion.   Now, I am comparing it to Risen and Gothic 1&2 because of the setting, protaganist and system.  It is not an action RPG.  It is not Diablo, Skyrim  Choices can matter to how the quests resolve and the story progesses.  There is action and prompts for traps.  Combat isn't the easiest, either to use or to survive against the monsters until a few tricks are learned.  All in all, I recommend the game if you like RPGs or wish to try one.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
												A good follow-up to the original.  It takes place a couple of years after Risen 1.  It was kinda wierd to go from a heavy medieval theme in Risen 1 to a heavy pirate theme in Risen 2, but I kind of liked it.My biggest problem in the first installment was the combat and the sticky focusing.  Sticky focus is gone, and it makes a HUGE difference in gameplay for PC users.  It's much easier to control and maneuver your character once you get used to it.  Dodge roll is your friend and incredibly powerful in it's defensive capability.  Once you get the timing and the angles you won't even bother with parry.At first I thought they pulled a 180 and made combat just as difficult as the first one but in a different way.  They took away a lot of the timed attacks and blocking that was notorious in Risen 1, and added what felt like a button mashing system for Risen 2.  Different style, same frustration.  Once you get a bit of Glory (XP) and put a few points into Blades you can get access to riposte and powerful riposte but I never bothered to build it past 6/10.  The real game changer was getting a bit of gear and access to muskets.  This made combat a LOT easier.  Dodge roll then musket shot, repeat.  There is also the addition of the companion system.  This allows you to take a companion with you for most of the game.  It's a huge help to have mobs focus on another npc or have a pack focus on you while they kill them off 1 by 1.  Overall I'd say this was an improvement in the combat system.Equipment is a lot better in the sense that, it felt you had a little bit of choice in what you could use, at least more than Risen 1.  I focused on Thief-skill, Musket, and Toughness items but you could just as easily build a more melee centric or voodoo based class.I feel that they improved the leveling and skill selection system as well.  Killing mobs, completing quests, etc gives you Glory.  Glory is spent to increase your main attributes: Blades, Firearms, Toughness, Cunning, and Voodoo.  Each of these Attributes affects 3 skills.  Talents that give you better abilities, both passive and active can be purchased with gold via trainers IF your main attribute is high enough.  So there's quite a bit of flexibility with character customization.Overall I really enjoyed this game.  More so than the original, but mainly because I didn't have to wait until the end of the game for combat to be easier and the addition of the companion system.  Definitely recommend this whether you enjoyed the first Risen or not.  It's a continuation of the first game but it can be played as a stand alone.

content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												Risen 2: Dark Waters – the game from the German developers from Piranha Bytes. The protagonist of the first part of the series is already faced with the pirates on the island of Faranga. But now, freed Titans create storms, drown ships and sea settlements and claim the lives of hundreds of marine civilians. Here we come, the hero of Faranga, in order to save the day, and destroy the raging Mara the Titan. Our old friends will help us with this, such as the daughter of a famous pirate Captain Steel Beard, Patty.In the second part of the trilogy, the protagonist becomes a pirate, in order to enlist the support of the local filibusters and Captain Steel Beard. The plot, as it is stuck at Piranha Bytes, banal. We are looking for treasure using old maps, swim to the islands in search of adventure, drink rum in the port taverns, fire at bottles, general are living a normal life of the average pirate. From untypical for pirates, we are destroying sea monsters created by the Titans, travel to the realm of the dead and looking for artifacts to defeat the villain. The plot - not the main advantage of Risen and Gothic series, it is simple, does not stand out, but sometimes intriguing and exciting.Graphics became more beautiful, brighter. Beautiful tropical landscapes, ancient ruins and settlements look amazing, the graphics pleases the eye. The visual effects are better, more realistic. The monsters, characters and various wild animals looks wonderful with textures of high quality. In visual terms, it is the same Risen 1, only better. The only thing that looks bad, it's character animation, it is terrible as before.The role-playing system has changed. There is no more magic but voodoo witchcraft, but there are guns and pistols. Now, the main character can treat the characters and convince them, he can tame parrots and monkeys and use them to steal items. Now we have many different talents, abilities and skills, their numbers literally dazzled. It's very interesting to develop and put into practice.It is fashionable to make games easier for consumers. Risen 2: Dark Waters does not suffer the same fate. The game is very hard, the combat system is no exception, especially in the early stages of the game when we do not even know how to counterattack or use witchcraft and shoot straight with rifles and pistols. Money is not always enough: there is nothing to heal yourself, a weak weapon, nothing to pay for skills training and so on. It difficult to gain experience, and as result we cannot learn all skills in one walkthrough, it is necessary to distribute the experience points wisely, learning only what is necessary.Risen 2 has so much content to offer, so many side quests, worlds to explore, everything. I have put almost fifty hours into this game, doing all of the side quests, a good amount of grinding and of course the main story. It's very rare these days to find a game this good that gives you that amount of gameplay. As a result, we can say that the atmosphere of piracy transferred perfectly, as in visual terms and in terms of the atmosphere. The game is to play it. All will be happy, especially those who love the pirate theme. Yo-ho-ho!

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												The Risen 2 development team's discussions must have included lines such as these: "It doesn't have to actually look like the player character is jumping, so long as he is moving through the air." "The player doesn't need to feel like they're controlling the combat - we'll just have them try to press buttons at enemies until they die." - "Explain the game mechanics to the player? Meh, Dark Souls doesn't do that, either." There is one word that perfectly described Risen 2: "curde", as in "crudely made". So why am I actually recommending this game? Well, because it's crudeness is sort of a "Mount & Blade"-like crudeness.Yes, Risen 2 is crude. But it's also charming and captivating. How captivating? Well, I was really pining to play Dark Souls again while playing Risen 2, put I decided to put it off. The dialogue in this game is well written, though not always well voice-acted. The characters are all you'd expect from a pirate game: drunks, thieves, ruffians and weirdos litter the various islands of its world. But its biggest asset is the sense of exploration that it gives the player. It always makes you curious for the next thing. I don't know how they did it, but ever since Gothic 1, Piranha Bytes has been able to make running around and picking up random stuff off the ground an intriguing passtime. But that is not all that Risen 2 is, of course. There are many interesting conversations to have, talents to learn, quests to undertake and enemies to slay, despite the abysmal combat system - seriously, it takes the guy like 2 seconds to execute the input! Could be that I'm playing with a controller, but it's just so much more fun.Get the game on a bargain and enjoy!

												What happened to Risen? I recommended the first very highly as the "Dark souls of RPGs", but something along the way went missing in Risen 2. It's got the same unforgiving combat and rough-around-the-edges questing systems that I loved about the first, but a piece of the magic is gone. All the jungle areas were too similar, and too big. And I didn't encounter any areas that really interested me, teasing me to brave monsters above my pay grade in exchange for fabulous game breaking rewards. We fight monkeys and boars in this game. I had to remove it after a few hours. Maybe it gets better later on, but I just couldn't get through it. Disappointed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
												I would recommend this game to people who have already played and enjoyed PB's previous games in the Gothic or Risen series. This is probably not a good place for newcomers to get introduced to the studio's unique style of RPGs.  Risen 2 could have been so much more. For every step forward from the excellent Risen, there are several steps back. Combat, while functional, is clunkier than it should be and plays like a low rent version of The Witcher 2's combat. Parts of the game seem unfinished—some of the skills, like the promising monkey training and intimidation skills, are poorly implemented into the game. Worse of all, the dialogue and character animations seem like they came out of a game from the 90s. So why the recommendation? For all its faults, Risen 2 still manages to capture what makes PB's games so enjoyable. Few developers craft such lush, believable worlds that are fun and rewarding to explore. While there are a ton of quests of varying quality, the game really shines when the player is just exploring new areas, with the danger of coming across enemies more powerful than you.  Unfortunately, technical issues still plague this game. Nvidia users are advised to uninstall any 3D Vision components, as it's been known to mess with framerates. Also, a simple "Anti Warp" mod is needed to fix the awful and emersion-breaking foliage warping problems.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2016
												It's somewhat to play, but very rough and un-polished. The combat is VERY bad, the skill/XP system is worse and seems mostly half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and not thought-out. The quests and the storyline are kind of domb, but not as dumb as literally every main character in the game. The characters have one-liners that they repeat to no end, and it gets annoying.I have to go back to the combat, because it's legendarily bad. It just queues your actions when another action is in progress,  and it's impossible to stop the queued actions. For example, you press attack three times, you cannot do ANYTHING until you've attacked three times. ANYTHING includes pausing the game, running away, using secondary attack, opening inventory etc. but not using items in your quickbar, which is a relief, because you need all that healing when you can't dodge any attacks.The skill system is the weirdest. You have "Glory" which is XP and used to increase your 4 base talents, which increase their 3 or so each sub-talents. The talents are useless if you don't know any skills, which you need GOLD to learn, by paying someone and also having the required talent (and prerequisite skill) levels. The XP amount needed to increase the talents is also half-assedly chosen, just multiply the talent level by 1000.The movement is hilarious, Jumping works like if you are put on an invisible conveyor belt that transports you 0.5 meter up and 1 meter forward.The thieving system is half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you need to learn two skils and then just keep increasing your thievery skill and you can open any lock, if you have a lockpick, that is. You can also pick pockets, but you do this by talking to someone, instead of sneaking up to them. And you can only pickpocket certain characters at certain times. Lockpicking is the least challenging in all the RPG games, you just move the mouse back and forth and it will open, you can't fail.You can dig for gold and treasure, the treasure appears as a literal red X on the spot  once you have the map. You need a shovel for digging treasure and a pickaxe for mining gold (there are very few randomly scattered gold veins). You can have many pickaxes and shovels and they are classified under consumables, but they never get consumed, like the lockpick. Seems like they were maybe planning to make them consumable? I don't know.One good thing is, that you can skip all dialogue sentences and it makes the horribly stretched-out dialogues more bearable.

number of helpful: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												I'm a huge fan of Risen, so although I expected a reasonable game, I really didn't expect to enjoy Risen 2 more than its predecessor.Both are third person adventures, both have solid stories that generate cause and effect with a beginning, middle and end.  In Risen 2 you play a pirate with a number of companions available who are actually useful.  I'm not a fan of using companions.  I play Skyrim without them unless forced by a quest.  In Risen 2, the fact your companions get stuck in and not stuck in your way is a bonus.Risen 2 is an exciting game.  With Patty, Captain Steelbeard's daughter from Risen, you journey across the sea to various islands, tracking down legendary weapons, digging up treasure and deciding which faction you want to side with.  You have plenty of choice regarding how you develop your character and teachers are to be found in every port.  I've focused on being a thief and just love the trained monkey.  NCPs talk to it, ask what its up to, does it want a drink - silly detail, but wonderfully immersive.  Parrots also feature and are fun as well as useful.General control of your character is straightforward but fights are another story.  Combat in Risen 2 has been slated for being poor but, like Dungeon Lords and Venetica, you need to use timing and avoidance to make the most of your abilities.  You also use both hands.  Your right has a sword, spear or voodoo doll, your left a pistol, coconut, knife, parrot, sand/salt.  Plus, you can kick an enemy.  The only two handed weapon I've found to date is a musket.  The Boss battles are hard, but enjoyable.  This isn't an easy game, the combat is difficult to master, but very satisfying once you have.  I've also noticed there is often more than one way to complete a quest.Yes, I did say a voodoo doll is a weapon.  Rather than using magic as we gamers generally understand and know it, Risen 2 has voodoo.  At times it's quite brilliant and has given me some of the biggest laughs I've had from a game for a long time.  There is a lot of humour present in the dialogue.  Combine this with taking someone over by waving a doll at them and..... well, I'll let you find out. The dialogue also contains a fair amount of cussing - but then you're amongst pirates.  Joking aside, this is not a game you would want your children listening to, the language is very adult.  But, if you enjoy action packed, third person RPGs, have a look at this one.  It's very enjoyable and I'm totally hooked.

												This is a bad game.  I wanted to give it a thumbs up, but I can't justify doing that.  I had fun, but it took several hours of grinding to get to a point that I enjoyed it.The quests are mostly well done.  The maps are nice, too.The graphics are okay, not great.  However, even on the lowest settings, the game still runs slow on a modern machine that exceeds system requirements.  Getting your character to level up is a pain.  The economy is bad, and I grew tired of picking up junk off the jungle floor.  You have to spend huge amounts of gold that is hard to accumulate in order to buy skills, like the ability to pick locks, block, kick or use heavy attacks.  Loot every location, kill every foe in the game, and you're thousands of experience points and gold currency from being able to use the character to his full potential.  Your tutor for swordsmanship also stops being available to you late in the game, when you would be able to learn skills from him.  Due to the unresponsive controls and poor effort put into the combat system, it is next to impossible to dodge, parry or riposte.The Earth Temple (your first boss battle) is the climax of the game.  It doesn't last very long, and gets very dull after you beat down the extraordinarily tough minions.Eldric is the stupidest name you could give to the druid in the DLC.This game is a shameless knock-off of all the Pirates of the Carribean movies and disappoints.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2014
												I find Risen 2 as a highly underrated but great successor of Gothic 1 and 2 and Risen games (it's made by the same developers to those who do not know). In fact, I personaly like it much more than first Risen. It has many rough edges, there are visual glitches, few dialog errors (but no game breaking ones), combat is clunky and hard at the start, but that changes with more skills You learn yet it remains challenging. I liked that opponents had their weakneses which you can take advantage of (for example: you can turn giant crabs on their back with kicking). There are often 2 or more ways to solve a quest. I enjoyed being a thief again as I enjoyed it in good old Gothic: Night of the Raven. Atmosphere is great especially when there is a thunderstorm. Locations are smaller than in previous game, but they feel more... personal, detailed and thought trough and it's fun to just explore (not to mention that it's also rewarding). Story isn't that breath-taking, it's a classical "have to save the world" story, but I liked it, it goes within the footsteps of Gothic saga. Characters are deeper then in Risen 1 and I found a few memorable ones which is a huge improvement from the previous game, from which I don't remember a single character (except for Patty, which is also accompaniing you in Risen 2).Graphics are (at least for me) fine looking, sometimes even gorgeous (Storms, Sunrise, Dawn) and are not HW demanding as I could play it even on my old work notebook.I still didn't finish it after 25+ hours of gameplay, but so far I would give the game 8 out of 10. I can only recommend it for all the other RPG-positive players out there.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												Risen 2 is more focused on pirates than the first game, and you actually become a pirate yourself to safe the world again fighting slightly more interesting creatures and meeting interesting folk, who you later end up forgetting about.Shifting to the more pirate kind of world, mages have been removed from the game with a mention somewhere in the dialogue as to why. Instead of mages we now have Voodoo witches, the natives living on some islands. The bows and crossbows have been removed and instead we have pistols, shotguns and muskets.The leveling up has been changed from how it was in the first game. You now earn Glory, which kind of represents your XP. Glory can be used on the character menu to upgrade your stats. There are still trainers who you need to pay to learn spesific skills like smithing or how to do a riposte. This was confusing to me at the beginning and it took a while before I figured that I can buy skills, but need specific stat level to do so.The graphics are rather good and modern looking, but sometimes there would be glitches where while walking towards a tree, you'd see its leaves becoming smaller as you got closer, until they were the right size. The menu screen has been changed so that you can easily access all the info you need from any selection you're looking at. This also makes the game look a bit clumsy at the beginning, if you start right away from the first game, since it is completely different.The game itself is much more bug free than its predecessor, but sometimes you'd encounter minor bugs that don't harm playability.Fights are still rather difficult and you'll be using quick save a lot. During my 20 or so gameplay hours I saved over 2200 times (Which was a tad too much than needed, but better save than sorry). This is also my biggest complain about the game. Using quick save creates a completely new save and doesn't overwrite the older one. This means that I had over 2200 save files at the end and the game started to load longer. Easily fixable by removing the older saves though.Overally a great game after you get used to the new mechanics, but a lot less fantasy like when compared to the first game. If you like pirate stuff and RPG's, then this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2015
												I saw this game sitting in my steam list - no idea how I got it - and decided to give it a go.It seemed like an interesting pirate-style RPG, however when I started into the game I was given the intro of a very generic plot (which I won't spoil in case someone actually wants to try this for some reason).The game looks okay, not great by any means, until you leave the starting area that is. The pop-in is unbearable (at highest settings mind you). Walking 5 meters from a tree makes half of it's leaves dissapear, textures flicker in the distance, and lighting bug out _everywhere_.The gameplay is even worse, after completing the tutorial you're put out into the "open" world (which from the little I saw in my 20 minutes of trying to get the game to work was not very open at all).Here you will HAVE to do "side" fetch and work quests to get money to buy the items REQUIRED TO PROGRESS IN THE GAME, but the game does *NOT* tell you this, not only that, but *GIVES YOU THE OPTION TO DECLINE THE JOBS*.I successfully got stuck here because I didn't have enough money to continue and there were no NPCs I could talk to, or any dialogue options to bring back the possibility of getting money. It tells you "Save often" on the loading screen, this most be why.I came across numerous physics glitches, and the AI seems like they were copy/pasted from another game and not even slightly adapted. They would spin around in circles randomly, have trouble sitting in chairs (walk around them for a good minute and a half first) and have trouble attacking you as well.The combat is clunky and floaty at the same time, if you hit an enemy they slide back an unreal distance without even playing an animation, there is only 1 button to attack, no heavy attacks, no other types of attacks.You will spend most of the game pressing one button, and ignoring the "blocking" because it's literally useless.Along with that, the framerate, for a game that looks barely on-par at best rarely exceeds 45fps even in the starting area on an R9-270.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												This review is based on the core game (no DLC), after the combat fix.Risen 2 received mixed reviews on release.  Reviewers complained that the combat was too difficult or tedious, that the game is exposition heavy, that the game is too linear at the start, and that the game should have a more earnest tone.Deadly Waters has classic Gothic-style combat.  At the beginning, you can attack and dodge.  Over the course of the game, as you gain experience and seek training, you learn additional moves (parry, riposte, shoot your gun, kick, throw sand in their eyes, etc.)  Each new mechanic you unlock makes you a better fighter, if you are skillful at deploying your new skill.  Every one of your character stats has an impact on combat, though swords/guns/toughness have the most obvious effect.  The game IS combat heavy.  Because raising skills costs increasing amounts of experience, it's obvious that having a base level in all skills is the most efficient way to have a capable character (e.g., raising voodoo from 4 to 5 would cost the same as raising all other skills from 1 to 2).  Characters who overspecialize may run into tough times.  The combat also rewards smart approaches, like luring dangerous enemies to allies or working with a partner to take down a particularly tough enemy (one of the hardest enemies in the game can be killed in the first island if you work with your partner, Patty).Lockpicking and pickpocketing are uniquely implemented.  If you meet a skill check, you can pickpocket someone you're talking to and you're treated to a little special dialogue.  I like that this kept me from pickpocketing the whole world (I'm looking at you, Fallout).  There are plenty of locked chests, opened by running a pick along a series of tumblers.  It's basically working out the combination of how to travel a line, but I appreciated a different look at lockpicking.  You'll either find it tedious or revel in your growing mastery of the minigame.This is a thing about Gothic and Risen.  You have to enjoy the mastery of your skills.  It's expensive to level a character and train them to gain a new ability - you have to want to use that ability, to make it pay off, to make it a part of your mastery of the game world.  The dialogue is sparse, sometimes amusing, and most of it can be skipped if you absolutely must.  Still, I don't understand how reviewers could complain about the quantity of exposition in this game - it's really very minimal, the bulk of your time is spent exploring and fighting wildlife.  It has nowhere near the amount of dialogue as Fallouts 1-3/NV, Oblivion, Arcanum, Bloodlines.Well, I could go on and on.  But like the game, I'll just cut myself off here.  When Deadly Waters has shown you its hand, it abruptly wraps up - unlike the dreary extended ending of Risen.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Best pirate game I've played. Not a bad RPG all in all, however if you prefer traditional RPGs I recommend this games predecessor or the original Gothic franchise. This game has a slightly different approach compared to the traditional level up with exp progression, however I don't find this irritating at all. Gorgeous scenery and fun quests, somewhat linear in places, however its not that far into the game, that you get access to the entire world for you to explore. I haven't played Treasure Isle dlc yet, but the air temple is interesting as a quest. Good build up and search for the temple, yet not much happens once you've found it, but good way to collect experience for later on. The natives are really fun to play around and the inquisition has had quite a few interesting alterations compared to the previous game. Funny dialogue. To begin with I felt the pirate theme was somewhat forced, however its easy to get used to and it truly does seem like a plausible world (also I love pirate themed stuff). The interaction with other characters is good, I haven't noticed any flaws (though there are a couple of intentionally irritating characters). Some really good skills to pick and choose from and the ending isn't dissappointing at all, and ties up loose ends with all recruited shipmates. For older pcs (dual core and low graphics memory) this game will be difficult to play, even if it says you meet the minimum requirements, quad core is I think best suited for minimum, game works brilliantly with 6 core and 2gb graphics memory (at least). All in all, I would recommend this to any fan of rpgs, however if you don't like alternative gameplay and prefer traditional rpgs (this game is non turn based in battle), this isn't really for you. I personally love it and if you love this (as mentioned before), definately try Risen 1 and the Gothic trilogy (with community patches). Hope this was helpful!

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Plain and simple Risen 2 is an excellent game, with one flaw: combat. Combat goes from outright insane to♥♥♥♥♥♥easy and bosring over the game. Other than that, Risen 2 is an awesome game perfectly in line with other works from Piranha Bytes. In fact, I was surprised at how smoothly they managed to integrate a piratey settings with the cloak&dagger, sword&sorcery from Risen (and, previously, Cothic I and II: whose universe is technically unrelated to this one, although it does not really feel so).Overall, the game is really nice, and has an old-school feeling to it. risen 2 even caters some funny moments and the attempt at a couple of more serious ones (mostly crippled by the voice-acting, otherwise fine). The story is compelling enough and paced well enough to get you playing through all of it, there is certain (however small) degree of "sandbox", and some unexplored potential, but the game plays well and it turns out to be really enjoyable, and just the right length.8/10

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												This game isn't what I loved about Risen 1 - well written strong characters (like Inquisitor) and also all the characters in camps; mysterious, but still logic, escalating, complex story - for me one of the best; visible (not just skills but also cosmetic) progress of player's character and great music. Also realistic fighting system - with stuns, interruptions, dodges - different tactics against animals/humen/insects/other races. And cool interiors - like laboratory in monastery or the flame sanctuary. It seems to me that the devs tried to change features that players who didn't like their games wanted to change, but what their fans loved about Risen 1 is not really there. Yes, you can choose which island you will visit first, graphic is better, the story is still good, but there is no unknown hero  you could customize and you would be curious where it would develop - you play a well known hero who doesn't evolve in anything - he still looks the same, he talks like he knows it all, not even learning voodoo would change him to something more mystic. The islands have still nice natives/cities, but with no gradation - you just do some quests for them and that is all. Maybe it would be better if they would use the world of Risen but not the old hero - like they did it in Dragon Age - you could meet him, but your new hero would be yours and you could do really free choices. But still I would recommend this game - it is still a good game with a pirate theme. The fighting system is a torso of what it was before - so it wouldn't be difficult to learn it probably, but it is not rescripted, so it doesn't work as it could if it would be made new, but otherwise everything else is OK.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												This game isn't what I loved about Risen 1 - well written strong characters (like Inquisitor) and also all the characters in camps; mysterious, but still logic, escalating, complex story - for me one of the best; visible (not just skills but also cosmetic) progress of player's character and great music. Also realistic fighting system - with stuns, interruptions, dodges - different tactics against animals/humen/insects/other races. And cool interiors - like laboratory in monastery or the flame sanctuary. It seems to me that the devs tried to change features that players who didn't like their games wanted to change, but what their fans loved about Risen 1 is not really there. Yes, you can choose which island you will visit first, graphic is better, the story is still good, but there is no unknown hero  you could customize and you would be curious where it would develop - you play a well known hero who doesn't evolve in anything - he still looks the same, he talks like he knows it all, not even learning voodoo would change him to something more mystic. The islands have still nice natives/cities, but with no gradation - you just do some quests for them and that is all. Maybe it would be better if they would use the world of Risen but not the old hero - like they did it in Dragon Age - you could meet him, but your new hero would be yours and you could do really free choices. But still I would recommend this game - it is still a good game with a pirate theme. The fighting system is a torso of what it was before - so it wouldn't be difficult to learn it probably, but it is not rescripted, so it doesn't work as it could if it would be made new, but otherwise everything else is OK.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												I really, really like this game.I played it back when it was released on xbox360 (rented it), and really had a good time playing it, but didn't know if I wanted to spend $40 or whatever on it at that time.Then I found it on sale on Steam, for dirt cheap, and having progressed farther than I did when I had rented it, in hindsight I would now say that that $40 might have been well spent.If you are going into to it looking for a triple-A title like Assassin's Creed or Skyrim, you are probably going to be a little dissappointed.  However, if you go into it not expecting it to strictly adhere to standards set by other titles, looking for something similar to Skyrim but focused on pirates and voodoo instead of dragons and magic, you might be rather surprised with what you find.  I find the voice acting somewhere between entertaining to quite good.  The tropical ambiance, settlements (Inquisition, pirates, and savages), and wildlife look great.  The story is interesting for the most part (I found myself to be more inclined towards free-roaming and side-questing).So in conclusion, if you are like me and actually enjoyed Two Worlds 2, I think that you would also have a great time with this.  Ironic to end a review by compairing it to another game when I just tried to impress upon those reading to NOT do exactly that when going into it, but there you have it. :D10/10 Would contridict myself in a review and post it anyway again

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Well I think that one of my favorite RPG game devs is Piranha Bytes, since Gothic series I have been playing all of their releases (Gothic series and Risen).Risen 2 is a bit different from the others is purely based on pirate adventures, but still keeps the essence from its predecessors, for example look and feel, exploring the world and always finding nice surprises, these little details are the ones that make you feel the game, not like many others just empty building shells, lifeless landscapes, etc.I dont understand why so many people complain about the pirate thing, I mean if they know about Piranha Bytes work they would know that the pirate touch has been present since Gothic, so I'm ok with it.In conclusion I would give the game 9/10 it is really a fun game and ok storyline, combat mechanics are not too bad, beautiful landscapes, only thing I didnt like is the lack of variety for outfits, it has plenty of weapons, fairly balanced  by the way, eventhough they seem to have high specs they are not too OP, so you still get to enjoy part of the fights.Well if you are looking to kill some time with a different RPG game I would suggest Risen 2 Dark Waters ;)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2013
												Full of potential and other issues. The graphics are well done although distant fauna "blooms" visably and restores have objects popping up from the depths of the programmed underworld - which is funny to watch. Movement is a little stiff but one gets used to it. The quests are reasonable, the leveling up is competent. I just wish that they had not fired the QA team after the second of several islands became available. That's the only thing that made sense to me. The bugs and inconsistencies in dialogue, the growing graphics stuttering, all this and more grew worse and worse as the game progressed. It got to the point where I was restarting every hour just to keep playing. And that is just one issue, I can think of more off the top of my head. Each of them by themself is a non-breaking issue. You can still play, you can still win (although you may go Huh?) but when you put them all together, well - it's just tiring.I REALLY wanted this. The premise is first rate, the original was fun if not a little "off" at times, and then it went downhill in the first scene. I still played the stubborn pirate like a stubborn pirate and put up with it until completed. Filled with a sense of accomplishment I went back to mine a few steam achievements - only to discover more quirks preventing further play. Starting over is not a worth-while option.In fact, I'm not sure starting at all was a good decision in hindsight.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2014
												I would like to finish this game, just to complete the story, but the gameplay itself is just too tedious for me to justify wasting all that time.This saddens me, because I generally like the world and exploration. The story isn't mind blowing - but hey, Pirates, Sea Gods, and Colonial might, there's nothing wrong with any of that and it would make for an enjoyable jaunt if only the gameplay held up to allow the story to be told.Combat is slow and uninspired. I've never found combat in a Gothic game to be particularly good, this just took the cake in terms of rigidity and slowness. It's a bit like Demon Souls with crappy controls (which basically makes the combat). Reading a few of the other reviews, I guess I responded quite negatively to the combat as you would expect SOME sort of improvement in the combat of this series, but things have not progressed since Gothic 2. Back then there was so much NEW stuff that these games were doing, that you could accept a bit of dodgy combat stuff. But this isn't new. It's prettier, and in a different setting, but there's nothing new here.Toward the end of my session I found myself switching on God mode, purely so I could skip through most of the frustratingly combat stuff and focus on the story and exploration. But after a few hours I thought to myself, "What am I doing? This isn't how the game is supposed to be played". The whole point of this uncompromising style was that there were some places you just weren't supposed to go at the start, but God mode ruins that - even though I wasn't trying to break it, I just couldn't be bothered dealing with the combat system.So if I felt inclined to destroy the unique aspect of this series, just so I could run around talking to people and gathering stuff, that basically signals that something is horribly wrong with the balance of this game.Graphically it's pretty. Story is ok, and the world is actually quite interesting. Kudos for that.But I won't be getting back into this series until something changes with the combat. Enough time has passed that this cannot be accepted anymore.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												What's improved in this sequel? Early combat, graphics. story, game design/environment, quests, camera a little bitStayed the same? Movement, some of the combat (sometimes you can get "attack-locked", meaning a monster keeps attacking you so fast you cant block.. this is very frustrating) as well as the voice acting. The game bugs out as well every now and then.Made it worse? Picking up items like food is considered stealing and makes guards angry at you even though the food was clearly there on display for visitors to take. what the ♥♥♥♥? Also the low early gold really holds you back and you waste a lot of time going back and forth between camps/bases. Lightning strikes (weather) are more like flashes and don't look good. There is a shortage of food because of having to fight so many enemies with flawed combat.This is a early first impression "review". I just want to say that the game is very similar to the first one of the series and the combat/movement and overwhelming enemies thing is still there. 8.5/10 so far, with combat holding it back. Will edit this after I'm done with the game.

												The reviews that the critics gave this game were right.I just can't see how people can stand up for this game, it's just plain bad.First of all, the animations  the characters have during conversations are just disturbingly bad to watch, I mean seriously who moves there hands like that when they are talking about going down to the beach to get some washed up boxes?The voice acting as well is very poor. Also, your companion is usless, if you are trying to be stealthy or trying different tactics, the companions ai will ignore everying and just run around doing nothing. I was fighting a group of enemy mobs and she didnt not help at all with my fight against them, she just sat back and kept cycling through her bland dialouge, when i was about to finish off the last mob however, she decided to one shot it with her musket -_-. The combat in this game too is just so boring, theres nothing to it but just swinging your sword and waing every 90 second to shoot your musket, theres a parry mechanic too but that seemed to never work for me when i used it.Overall my expiernce in this game was very poor, I wouldn't even recomend it for the 5$ I payed for it.3/10 There are so many better games out there.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												If you liked Risen 1 or Gothic games, you will like Risen 2.  If you are new to the series well... you will either love it or hate it.  Risen games, like the older Gothic games, are generally viewed favorably with the exception they have some plot holes, story holes, and bugs.  Normally that would be really bad but there just aren't that many good RPGs of this type out there to choose from... and what does work, works well.  The exploration and adventure parts of this game are above average, as well as the background music.  I will add parts of this game are really stupid, and others very frustrating.... but was it worth it?  Yes, especially if you can nab it at a steep discount.  If you are looking for a simple point and click, this isn't for you... if you like a challenge and can get through the first 10 hours without breaking your keyboard then I'd say your in for a great time.  If your system can handle it, the graphics on Ultra setting are still good as of Dec 2013.  The good:  Lots of good quests, exploration, suprises, good loot, many ways to accomplish tasksThe bad:  Fights are very, very frustrating in the beginning... but yes it does get better as you go.In closing, I'd say do yourself a favor and invest 10 hours before you give up on it.... if after that point you aren't sucked in a bit, then go ahead and call it a day as this game is not for you.

content:
Posted: April 5
												Arr! Risen 2 can be described as Gothic with better graphics and with pirates. You embark on an adventure as a spy for the Inquisition and become a pirate captain in the process. What will you do from there? Will you improve your piratey skills of thievery, intimidation and lockpicking? Or perhaps learn voodoo? Stay clear off any criminal action and try to be a decent lawful citizen? It's up to you how you approach the quests. The game is a bit limited at first, but as you progress and get your ship, you have a lot of location available to explore and need to find a way to get to others. The main character is a bit too posh for a pirate, but fun to play as. The visual part of the game might seem a bit outdated, but it's a 2012 game and the details are pretty nice to the eye. One of the nicest aspects of Risen 2 is the jungle. It's vivid and has a nice feel. The map has some hotspots for fast travel which really helps when switching locations.If you played Gothic and enjoyed the hermetic feeling of being forced to figure out a way to get out from a limited area that gives you a chance to learn the game mechanics, so that later you have a more vast variety of choices and locations -  this is the game you might want to check out. It's not Gothic, and the plot is very different, though.If you haven't played Gothic and don't know what to expect from the gameplay, be ready for a title that doesn't make it easy for the player when it comes for combat. You need to earn your way to improve your combat prowess, and also learn how to use the mechanics in the way that benefits you the most.Decent game and it's very fun to play.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2013
												Risen 2: Dark Waters gets a lot of things right. For example, the game has at times near photorealistic graphics; the leveling, experience (glory) systems are well balanced; and the difficulty on medium is challenging but not frustrating. Sometimes the graphics can just be average/good but they still feel quaint. Gold seems fairly difficult to come by and also seems well-balanced. There are some neat items/equipment and skills to buy with the limited gold you have. I didn't list all the positives. The game is pick up and play friendly with a save anywhere system. Not sure if you can save during fights. I give it an 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Well my first impression after opening the game was what the ♥♥♥♥ happened to the place I saved in "Risen 1". Then they introduce the Hero and I was like who the ♥♥♥♥ is this long haired, One-eyed ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥? I almost lost interest from the get-go. lolThen I played for a bit, now Commandant Carlos is now a fat dude. Well at least Patty was hotter than in the first game.After playing the game (and reading on the wiki) I now know what happened to the Nameless Hero. Apparently he was blamed for what happened in Faranga. Got his eye destroyed by the Monocle from Inquisitor Mendoza which turned out to be cursed. The ban of magic also forced him to let go of the titan armor (what a waste).All in All my final verdict is that Risen 1 is better and far more engaging than Risen 2, however Risen 2 is still a good game.Pros:There are a lot more place to explore in this game.You're a pirate? Yarrr?Animations are better at least there are a lot more diversity in the looks of NPC's.Companion System.....?Better fast travel than in Risen 1.If in 1 you got Lizardmen in 2 you'll get gargoyles that looks like dragons standing on 2 legs weilding an axe.You'll get to meet some of the people from Risen 1 in better graphics and new models.Cons:The animations are still clunky, but can be overlooked.Sometimes (Most of the time?) when exploring, it felt like a walking simulator.Lore didn't get me as hooked, so it felt like a chore to finish the game.The Pirate ship could have been more than Aesthetics, like naval battles, for cryin' out loud you have sea monsters.Professions (crafting) and Factions are useless.I've read that the game was rushed etc, so that's why it wasn't that polished but it's still a good game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
												I bought it for 75% off during winter sale, and the game was a lot of fun. Some quest were the usual "get me 10 things" or "kill the 5 somethings". But in general most of the quest were ok.I found some minor problems concerning bugs. Sometimes dialog options were not accessible anymore, when proceeding too far in the game. Some maximum skills cannot be learned, because the trainer does not provide you the dialog option after completing some main quests. Also some potions cannot be created, because the recipes cannot be bought. But cheats do exist ;-)Apart from that I can definitely recommend the game for all people who like action RPGs.Some hints for developing the character:- Forget voodoo and alchemy, it doesn't provide you combat magic. 99% of the potions raise your skills only for some seconds.- Raise your blade skills (counter attack) very early, because there is no trainer on the second island. It makes you very weak for some hours.- Raise your thief (lockpick) skills very early, because you will find many hidden and locked chests on the islands.- Smithing is not that important. You can create 4-6 standard blades and repair 4 special blades (you have to find first).Some other tips and comments:- For every item you want to craft, you have to find/buy/steal a recipe. They are very rare and expensive.- When you cannot open a chest, write down the position on a piece of paper. You will forget where to find it in the jungle of a certain island a second time.- After leaving for the final quest, you will not be able to return for completing open ones. After killing the last boss, the game ends.- You don't need the plants when not performing alchemy. So eat them to regenerate.- If you follow the voodoo path (helping the tribes): As soon as you can sail to the island of the dead, do it. It provides you a tool to summon someone.Well, that's all that comes to my mind.

content:
Posted: February 13
												It's the second game of the Risen trilogy. Honestly, the game seems to be placed in a different world and there's no feeling of playing a sequel. The story seemingly takes place in a different historical settings, like decades or even centuries has passed since the first chapter. All places visited, technology and architecture and even system of magic has been changed and game has no longer a fantasy-like appearance. Despite that fact, I think that the game is worth playing and gives the player an interesting story to uncover. I enjoyed the task of completing a crew for your ship and possibility of travelling with one companion at a time. It made long walks in the wilderness not as lonely as in the first game. I also really like that authors made gnomes into civilized race, instead of them being just monsters. One of them can even become your follower, a useful one if you want to quickly examine your fallen opponents. New magic system at first looked strange, but voodoo possesion turned out to be something fresh and interesting.  I recommend the game for people who like action RPG.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												Nice RPG from the same team that did the original Gothic. And less buggy than Gothic, I only found two glitches that affected game play. Although it's a sequal, it doesn't matter if you've played Risen or not as it is in another part of the world and you don't miss much. World was enjoyable, but backwards - the end of the game was stupidly easy, unlike the first. Unlike Gothic, the world isn't quite as dangerous (shadowbeasts ftw!), but just like Gothic, there's lots to discover and explore. Overall, an enjoyable game and well worth sinking in a good few hours to fully experiance the story.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												The game sucks.- Bad camera panning in and out during conversations - not smoothly, but jumping to a new zoom level by itself.- Zooming in/out with a controller is unnecessarily complicated and does not work very well (you have to push both axis joysticks and push one forward and the other down)- Absolutely crap sword fighting mechanics, just about the worst I saw in a game. You have just 1 basic attack and a parry mode which rarely works. No dodge ability so you have to just mash the attack button. You can get defeated by a random crab or whatever if you're unlucky to be hit constantly just when you want to attack, as it will interrupt your attack. I can't think of a game with worst combat mechanics. Oh and the pistol takes forever to reload (30-60 seconds as I recall, feels like an eternety) and often misses. Played iPhone games with better combat mechanics than this.- Terrible, completely terrible voice acting. It's not even synced to the characters.- Dialogues aren't that great either, the effort put into the dialogues and voices altogether is no better than on an iPhone game.- Story isn't great and the dialogues don't help make it better.- The main character jumps very weird. The DEV team should look into other games for how the jump should work.Graphics are nice, except that the environment looks nicer than the characters...Got this game in a bundle and still feels like I wasted my money.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												After completing the game, I have mixed feelings.First, you can't take this game seriously. It's got intricacies and bugs like none other. Everyone talks like they're speaking sign language. You will complete missions before you are given them. At times, you will breeze through the combat. Other times, you will fire 180 degrees away from the enemies, roll into attacks, and instead of casting or shooting, the character will put down their weapon. Fighting is fun when it works. A lot of the time, it doesn't.You are constantly picking flowers, and you can't help but look like a pansy. Cutscenes will skip without your consent. You can beat people up, rob them blind, and STILL they'll help you a few moments later. You recover healh slowly by eating food and quickly by drinking booze or sleeping on a random bed you happen across out in the open in the jungle. Auto-save will happen about once every 5 minutes to 3 hours.You spend the whole game searching for amulets to defeat the ultimate evil... but in the end you don't really ever use them. The second to last boss will be unreachable for most of the game, but every 12 seconds will alternate between using the same predictable attack, and opening itself for retaliation... A leviathan monster, the Kraken, capeable of sinking ships.The rest of the time... you wait.But, it's all-in-all, a pretty alright RPG. You have the leveling system, unlocking abilities, a choice between two factions, a gaggle of creatures with varying abilities, minigames. It's all nothing new, nothing you haven't seen plenty of times elsewhere. But it was still fun.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												I've actually published a long review for this game on another website but I'll try to list the most crucial points here:StoryAlthough this game is a direct sequel to the first game, it seems like all your previous choices were simply neglected. Despite the fact that the indigent hero saved the world before, he's now working as an employee for the Inquisition and is also an alcoholic. Well, since it's a game about pirates, there's that famous eye-patch cliché (alongside others, such as buried treasures), and the reason for that has to be one of the stupidest ideas I've ever seen. If you've already played the game you'll know what I'm saying. Oh, by the way, Patty is back... Anyway, if in the previous game you've created any positive expectative about her, in Risen 2 just a few moments under her presence is more than enough to make you wanna just shove her into one of the ship's cannons and fire her into oblivion.GameplayThe gameplay haven't changed much, except perhaps for the possibility of now being able to use firearms, which certainly makes life much easier when compared to the first game. The prices everywhere are still outrageous and the chests of loot that you find lying around are often filled with cheap and useless crap. Besides that, you may now have a companion to assist you during the battles, but the AI is extremely dumb when it comes to follow you, so it's not uncommon to fight several enemies all by yourself while your companion is "making out" with a tree or something. Compared to the first game, the fast travel method has significantly improved too. Ah, the main character's pocket still has the size of the universe!Graphics / SoundThe visuals look nice (I really like the day to night transition effects) and the OST isn't that bad either, although it's nothing exceptional. As for the voice acting, somehow they've managed to make it worse than before. For instance, it looks like the main character is a pothead by the way he speaks. As for the other characters, there're moments that are meant to be sad but the acting is so awful that it makes the scene extremely funny.GlitchesJust like in the first game, this one won't disappoint you when it comes to find these around, not to mention a few random crashes (although they're much less frustrating than on the first game). The weirdest one I've met during my gameplay happened right after I killed one of the bosses. After doing it, when I'd try to jump, I'd keep going higher and higher (I believe I can fly). Ah, it was also really funny to talk to a floating Patty.Overall, while this game brings many improvements compared to the first one, it still has a fair share of flaws (it also happens to be shorter too). To be fair, it's not a masterpiece but it's actually fun if you actually buy it with a nice discount.

												This is probably the worst game I've ever played.I'm not even sure where I should start with this. How did they ♥♥♥♥ up a pirate game?There's nothing redeeming about this mess, I'd tell you the story, but after two hours I already forgot it. Not even the graphics look good, it seems like they wanted to make something similar to The Witcher 2 with all the filters they used, but the overworld looks shallow and the filters and the overused bloom effect just manage to hurt your eyes. You can apparently just visit a few islands that in them barely have any content at all, a few houses, 5 to 10 NPCs and that's it. The animations are one of the worst things I've experienced in this generation, they are not even close to movements, and trust me you'll see plenty of them since every time a line of dialogue is spoken, the charachter talking will amuse you with them.And, by the way, the dialogues sound like they got random people off the street to record them. Even a kid could make something better than what they choose.But the worst thing about this is probably the combat system, if you really want to call it that. It's just a mess, there's no strategy, every ability costs too much to be bought and you'll spend the first 3 hours in this game just randomly slashing at enemies in the hope of killing them and then going back to a town to heal. And I'm not even sure if after the first terrible hours in the game it'll get better. This is neither fun or RPG-like, it's just boring, boring to the point I'm here wishing I had never payed that dollar in the Humble Bundle for this thing.Please, please, don't buy this, why does this have so many people playing it at once? I don't get it, am I the only one that can see how unfinished and unpolished this game is?

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												A thoroughly engaging pirate romp in a wonderfully designed open-world - that's how I'd summarize Risen 2.It's not perfect, but it's close to what I personally look for in my "perfect RPG". Rewarding exploration, open-world, interconnected dialog and questing system, interesting characters and story, tons of loot to plunder and adventure around every hand-crafted nook and cranny that you find. I would say this game is a must-play if you are into RPGs at all. At first I didn't think I would like a pirate setting as I'm more into medieval settings, but the setting was so well-crafted that I quickly became hooked until I completed the game in just about 60 hours.Well worth checking out if you're a fan of RPG games. Buy it now! :)

content:
Posted: June 2, 2012
												Since I own so many games I 'had' to rush through this one unfortunately. RPG's are usually to big to complete properly.If you've ever played the Gothic games (except 4) then you actually know how combat and learning skills work in Risen 2 as well. It's pretty much an exact copy. The fights can become tedious and frustrating sometimes, especially with the glitchy/cheaty AI. On the other hand it does feel good when you finally defeat that annoying opponent.The game is filled with quests and treasures and exploration is being rewarded. I remember Gothic 3 doing the same thing, meaning; lots of exploration and no(t) (too much) hand holding when doing quests. It gave a sense of immersion.The graphics are colorful most of the times and fit the theme well. The whole thing can become glitchy sometimes.The voice overs are ok-ish. They're not terribly bad. The writing is at times, though.I enjoyed Risen 2 a lot, and you can get twice the amount of playtime if you do literally everything.[Rating: 77/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												I enjoyed this, a good ~40 hours of adventure, exploration, story and combat. It has a major choice to make at the start that ends up branching quite significantly so there's a lot of room for replayability. This crashed on me once but with frequent autosaves it wasn't really an issue. The autosaves themselves also track quite far back for quite a number (easily 10+). Same for quick saves.I used a controller for this as there are only a few times you need to aim unless you want to use guns a lot but even then it's quite forgiving. The few minigames also tone down for the controller, switching back to keyboard/mouse for them doesn't give you an advantage as they then ramp back up difficulty wise.It's not necessary to have played the original but there are a few references to it here and there. The story can be completed in any order with a variety of ways to approach quests and solve problems. I found the combat quite difficult initially. I am confused by the low metacritic score. All in all this is a very solid choice for anyone who enjoys RPGs of this setting.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
												Outstanding game and a worthy successor for Gothic/Risen series (thanks to PB), but its release is a blatant rip-off ("thanks" to its publisher Deep Silver and their pseudo-DLC tactics, when they just cut out some of the game content and sell it separately for a significant price).The game design is just right. There's NO grinding, you really need to EARN gold and treasure search is interesting and satisfying.The graphics are breathtaking and lots of times I wanted to switch the game to first-person mode.The music by Tilman Sillescu is amazing. It's not Kai Rosenkratz anymore, but new composer did his job very, very well. The dialogues are well-written and characters are memorable. The only complaint I have about the plot is that portrayal of pirates here is not true, it's kiddish and very, very far from real.English voice acting is simply PHENOMENAL. It's such a rare case for videogames in general, you just need to listen it for yourself.As of 2014, there are almost no bugs. The left ones are very minor and don't ruin game experience.If you're long-time fan, you may find beginning of this game to be pretty disappointing. But in this case you really should give it a chance.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
												"Arrr... you scury sea dogs! I'm Guybrush Threepwood and I wanna be a pirate..." Wait a minute... thats the wrong game. Well at least after beating the first part of Risen I found myself on the quest on completing this one playing as  a pirate. The start of the game left me scratch my head a bit, as the story wasn't picking up the pace in comparision with the previous title. After a while (leaving the second island occuping your own ship) the quest to defeat the evil sea godess "Mara" is getting more interesting. In general the flumsy combat system and especially the use of firearms isn't much fun, however after beating a vicious enemy (finally) feels quite compelling. On the bright sight the setting and the companions you get during your "journey" is quite rewarding and the search for "legendary items" is keeping up the motivation (mine at least). In total the title has it's pro's and con's, but looking at my time I spent within this title I can recommend this title for people who like pirates and always wanted to command their own ship, like to use Voodoo magic/Firearms and want to collect treasures and legendary items.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												If your computer is running on a Nvidia driver, make sure 3D drivers aren't installed because the game will lag to ungodly proportions.With that out of the way, Risen 2 is certainly not perfect but it has its charms of a pirate game.  I didn't play the first game, so I wasn't as horribly disappointed like some other fans of the first game.  The animation is cheap, but the dialogue makes up for it and the graphics itself is nice with the tropical environment.  Since blood and violence don't warrant an M rating in my book, the excessive swearing does end up warranting a mature rating as pirates use sailor's language to talking about women's bodies, shagging organisms, and the f-word like it's going out of style.  The side quests were more interesting than the main story, sadly, but side quests are fun to do since you will have to run around town quite a bit or backtrack during the main quest.Gold is key here since combat is hard even on easy mode.  The learning curve is steep because you need to spend gold on learning how to dodge, parry, riposte, and other things.  Yes, you will have to spend a fortune to learn the skills necessary to survive.  Mashing X is going to be hard if you haven't saved money to learn how to dodge, parry, or counter attack.  A frustrating bit about the combat was that it took me a while to realize that going to the inventory to restore my health was a terrible idea, because the MC will have put away his sword and I had to quickly pull it out to guard.  But halfway through the game gets easier as you do a bunch of sidequests that award you glory points (for leveling up attributes) and gold.  Because it costs more and more glory points to level up an attribute (Ex: Level 2=1000, 3=2000, etc), it's wise to figure out what kind of fighting style you want, melee, voodoo, or rifles.  Toughness is important for staying alive and cunning helps to bypass speech checks that would save you the trouble of fighting or getting loot.  A tip is that you don't have to max out the attributes because points can be supplemented with your equipment's passive boosts, unless you want the achievement that comes with it.Overall, I'd say give this game a chance with low expectations when it goes on sale if you're looking for a lighthearted pirate adventure with some plot twist here and there.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Well, by today's standards the game mechanics might seem a little dated. You can even argue that it's a bad thing... However, if you were old enough to play Gothic (and, especially, Gothic II) back in the day, you'll know exactly what's in store with this game. If you did adore Gothic games (like I did), the chances are you'll enjoy Risen 2 as well.If you consider the game for its pirate setting, it's a worthy pick. The pirates constantly swear, drink, pick fights and look for treasures, and your hero fits the pirate shoes perfectly from the intro cutscene.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2012
												Risen 2 changes it main emphasis onto the pirate theme for the majority of the game & it absolutely pays off. Simply put: putting the focus on the pirating theme is excellent, as this game absolutely nails the pirates theme. From the envirionments to the actual atmosphere of the game-world and its actual inhabitants, the pirating theme here is just extremely well done + the player will get immersed into the game and its world.As always with PB's games, the level of interactivity & immersion factor is high; & NPC's run on schedules. There are choices to often make to finish quests differently, as usual. The camera is now unlocked, so moving left or right doesn't strafe. The up-side: this makes it easier to battle numerous enemies & swing directly to them. The down-side: to strafe now, you have to hold your Secondary Action key. These control changes do take some time to get used to, if you're used to Risen 1's controls. A key for rolling would've helped, since double-tapping a direction makes your character roll - which can happen accidentally. The feel of the combat itself & its controls do again feel clunky, even though this is par for the course w/ PB RPG's since Gothic 1. Even despite its few minor issues, Risen 2 is another really good RPG from PB & easy to reccommend.Grade = B

content:
Posted: January 3
												75 out of 100.It takes times (for me, 15 hours of play) to appreciate (or immerse into) this game. One of the main problems is that our hero is far from attractive, neither is his girl partner Patty. A role-playing game is a role-playing, hence if I do not feel for the main character, everything is meaningless. There are some racial issues in this game, some players may be offended.Though, after 15 hours of play I can gradually (how slow, compared to other RPGs) enjoy this game. I like the vodoo part, (you can become othere but when doing so it is not allowed to save the game, what a stupid design!) and the player really needs to "solve" quests, as there is no goal-indictator, rather than just clicking from one place to another following the auto quest-navigation system like many nowaday's RPGs. The graphic is superb, the music is good but too monotonic if you play a long time, the plot is average, the characters and actions are quite unattractive.
